The non-use of imprisonment as a criminal punishment in the rural antebellum South reflected the haphazard administration of criminal justice in these regions. Under the general [[criminal procedure]] of the day, victims of theft or violence swore out complaints before their local [[justice of the peace]], who in turn issued [[arrest warrant]]s for the accused.<ref name=autogenerated44 /> The county [[sheriff]] would execute the warrant and bring the defendant before a [[magistrate]] judge, who would conduct a [[preliminary hearing]], after which he could either dismiss the case or bind the accused over to the Superior Court for a [[grand jury]] hearing.<ref name=autogenerated44 /> (Some cases, however, particularly those involving moral offenses like drinking and gambling, were initiated by the [[grand jury]] of its own accord.)<ref name=autogenerated44 />
Criminal procedure in the antebellum rural South offered many avenues of escape to a criminal defendant, and only the poorest resided in the jail while awaiting trial or sentencing.<ref name=autogenerated44 /> Those defendants who did spend time in jail before trial had to wait for the prosecutor's biannual visit to their county.<ref name=autogenerated109>Ayers, 112.</ref> Southern prosecutors generally did not live in the local area where they prosecuted cases and were generally ill-prepared.<ref name=autogenerated109 /> Disinterested jurors were also hard to come by, given the generally intimate nature of rural Southern communities.<ref name=autogenerated10>Ayers, 113.</ref> Relative leniency in sentencing for appears to have marked most judicial proceedings for violent offenses—the most common.<ref name=autogenerated10 /> Historical evidence suggests that juries indicted a greater number of potential offenders than the judicial system could handle in the belief that many troublemakers—especially the landless—would leave the country altogether.<ref name=autogenerated69 />
Few immigrants or free blacks lived in the rural South in the pre-[[American Civil War|Civil War]] years,<ref name=autogenerated127>Ayers, 116.</ref> and slaves remained under the dominant control of a separate criminal justice system administered by planters throughout the period.<ref>Hindus, 131.</ref> Thus, most criminal defendants were Southern-born whites (and all socio-economic classes were represented on criminal dockets).<ref name=autogenerated127 /> Blacks occasionally came within the purview of the conventional criminal justice apparatus from their dealings with whites in the "gray market," among other offenses.<ref name=autogenerated123>Ayers, 131.</ref> But the danger to whites and blacks alike from illicit trading, the violence that often erupted at their meetings, and the tendency of whites to take advantage of their legally impotent black counterparties all made these occurrences relatively rare.<ref name=autogenerated123 />
===Reconstruction era=== The [[American Civil War]] and its aftermath witnessed renewed efforts to reform America's system and rationale for imprisonment.<ref name=autogenerated45>Christianson, 177.</ref> Most state prisons remained unchanged since the wave of [[Prison|penitentiary]] building during the [[Jacksonian Era]] and, as a result, were in a state of physical and administrative deterioration.<ref name=autogenerated45 /> [[Auburn Prison|Auburn]] and [[Eastern State Penitentiary|Eastern State]] penitentiaries, the paradigmatic prisons of Jacksonian reform, were little different.<ref name=autogenerated45 /> New reformers confronted the problems of decaying antebellum prisons with a new penal regime that focused on the rehabilitation of the individual—this time with an emphasis on using institutional inducements as a means of affecting behavioral change. At the same time, Reconstruction-era penology also focused on emerging "scientific" views of criminality related to [[race (human classification)|race]] and [[heredity]], as the post-war years witnessed the birth of a [[eugenics]] movement in the United States.
====Northern developments====
=====Brutality, immigration, eugenics, and "prisons as laboratories"===== Social historian [[David Rothman]] describes the story of post-reconstruction prison administration as one of decline from the ambitions [[Jacksonian Era|Jacksonian period]].<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 20–21.</ref> Facing major overcrowding and understaffing issues, prison officials reverted to "amazingly bizarre" methods of controlling their charges, Rothman writes.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 18.</ref> Among the punishments that proliferated in this period were: * '''The Pulley or Tying Up'''—Convicts were suspended by the wrists, fastened over their head, for anywhere from a few minutes to an hour. At [[Sing Sing]] Prison, where this treatment was especially popular a New York investigator related, "Men have been kept raised so long as to cause bleeding from the mouth, before the doctor would order the prisoner taken down."<ref>Qtd. in Rothman, ''Conscience'', 18–19.</ref> Wardens also used a variation on the pulley known as the "hooks," which involved tying the inmates' hands together and lashing them to the wall at chest height, forcing them to put most of their weight onto their toes.<ref name=autogenerated12>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 19.</ref> * '''The Iron Cap or "Cage"'''—The convict wore a case composed of small rods or bands of iron—which weighed between 6 ½ and 8 pounds—around the neck, and an iron band across the next and shoulders held it in place.<ref name=autogenerated12 /> * '''The Lash and Paddle'''—This traditional penitentiary punishment continued into the post-war era with some refinement—''i.e.'', weighted leather strips and aerated paddles were used instead of whips. The number of strokes was set to the offense and in some placed, like Massachusetts, limited by statute.<ref name=autogenerated12 /> [[Sing Sing]] convicts in the 1880s reportedly jumped from the upper galleries of the prison's cell blocks in an effort to break their legs and escape a paddling.<ref name=autogenerated52>Christianson, 184</ref> * '''Solitary Confinement ("The Dungeon")'''—Reconstruction-era inmates were locked in dark solitary cells, furnished only with a bucket, and fed short rations for disciplinary infractions (usually for a period of up to a week, but sometimes up to six or more).<ref name=autogenerated9>Rothman, Conscience, 20.</ref> * '''Straitjackets'''—Wardens used these as much for discipline as for inmate safety.<ref name=autogenerated9 /> * '''Brickbag'''—Convicts who would not work were forced in some institutions to wear a heavy bag (full of weighted objects).<ref name=autogenerated56>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 20.</ref> * '''Water Crib'''—Used at the Reconstruction-era prison in [[Kansas]], this disciplinary instrument involved the inmate's being placed in a coffin-like box about six-and-a-half feet long, thirty inches wide, and three-feet deep. The inmate would lie face down, his or her hands cuffed behind the back, while keepers slowly filled the crib with water to simulate drowning.<ref name=autogenerated56 />
Although wardens tended to believe these measures were necessary for control, contemporary observers generally found them "unquestionably cruel and unusual," according to [[David Rothman|Rothman]].<ref>Rothman, Conscience, 18.</ref>
Northern states continued to lease the labor of their convicts to private business interests in the post-war years. The [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Thirteenth Amendment]], adopted in 1865, expressly permitted slavery "as a punishment for a crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted."<ref>U.S. Const. amend. XIII.</ref> In Northern prisons, the state generally housed and fed inmate laborers, while contractors brought all necessary machinery to the prison facility and leased the inmates' time.<ref>Christianson, 183–84.</ref>
Abuses were common, according to investigative reporter Scott Christianson, as employers and guards tried to extract as much time and effort from prisoners as possible.<ref name=autogenerated5>Christianson, 184.</ref> At [[New Jersey|New Jersey's]] prison at [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]], after an inmate died while being "stretched" by the prison staff, a committee investigating discipline at the prison determined that officials had poured alcohol on epileptics and set them on fire to see if they were faking convulsions in order to skip work.<ref>Christianson 184.</ref> At an [[Ohio]] penitentiary, unproductive convicts were made to sit naked in puddles of water and receive electric shocks from an induction coil.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> In [[New York (state)|New York]], public investigations of practices in the state's prisons became increasingly frequent during the 1840s, 1860s, and 1870s—though with little actual effect on conditions.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> They revealed that a prisoner had been poisoned to death for not working in one institution; another was found to have been kept chained to the floor for ten months in solitary confinement, until he eventually suffered a mental breakdown.<ref name=autogenerated52 />
By and large, Americans of the 1870s, 1880s, and 1890s did little to address the disciplinary and other abuses in United States penitentiaries of the time.<ref name=autogenerated47>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 23.</ref> One reason for this apathy, according to authors Scott Christianson and [[David Rothman]], was the composition of contemporary prison populations. Following the Civil War, the volume of immigration to the United States increased alongside expanding nativist sentiment, which had been a fixture of national politics since long before the War.<ref name=autogenerated125>Christianson, 189; McPherson, 130–38.</ref> During the 1870s, as many as 3 million immigrants arrived on the shores of the United States. By the 1880s, the influx rose to 5.2 million, as immigrants fled persecution and unrest in eastern and southern Europe.<ref name=autogenerated103>Christianson, 190.</ref> This trend continued until immigration reached a zenith between 1904 and 1914 of 1 million persons per year.<ref name=autogenerated103 />
Already in the 1850s and 1860s, prisons (along with [[mental asylum|asylums]] for the mentally ill) were becoming the special preserve of the foreign-born and the poor.<ref name=autogenerated47 /> This trend accelerated as the nineteenth century drew to a close.<ref name=autogenerated47 /> In [[Illinois]], for example, 60 percent of inmates in 1890 were foreign-born or second-generation immigrants—[[Irish people|Irish]] and [[Germans|German]], mostly.<ref name=autogenerated47 /> Less than one-third of the [[Illinois]] inmates had completed grammar school, only 5 percent had a high school or college education, and the great majority held unskilled or semi-skilled jobs.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 23–24.</ref> In the 1890s [[California]], 45 percent of prisoners were foreign-born—predominantly of Chinese, Mexican, Irish, and German descent—and the majority were laborers, waiters, cooks, or farmers.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 24.</ref> Throughout the post-war years, the rate of imprisonment for foreign-born Americans was twice that of native-born ones; black Americans were incarcerated, North and South, at three times the rate of white Americans.<ref name=autogenerated103 />
The Civil War's end also witnessed the emergence of pseudo-scientific theories concerning biological superiority and inherited social inferiority.<ref name=autogenerated125 /> Commentators grafted the [[Darwinism|Darwinian]] concept of "[[survival of the fittest]]" onto notions of [[social Darwinism|social class]].<ref name=autogenerated103 /> [[Charles Loring Brace]], author of ''The Dangerous Classes of New York'' (1872), warned his readers that attempts to cure poverty through charity would backfire by lessening the poor's chance of survival.<ref name=autogenerated125 /> Richard L. Dugdale, civic-minded New York merchant, toured thirteen county jails during the 1870s as a voluntary inspector for the prestigious Prison Association of New York. Reflecting on his observations in later writings, Dugdale traced crime to hereditary criminality and promiscuity.<ref name=autogenerated125 />
These views on race and genetics, Christianson and [[David Rothman|Rothman]] conclude, affected the various official supervisory bodies established to monitor regulatory compliance in United States prisons.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 25; Christianson, 184.</ref> Although these monitoring boards (established either by the state executive or legislature) would ostensibly ferret out abuses in the prison system, in the end their apathy toward the incarcerated population rendered them largely ill-equipped for task of ensuring even humane care, [[David Rothman|Rothman]] argues.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 25</ref> State and federal judges, for their part, refrained from monitoring prison conditions until the 1950s.<ref>Gottschalk, 44–45.</ref>
Persistent beliefs in inherited criminality and social inferiority also stoked a growing [[eugenics]] movement during the [[Reconstruction Era]], which sought to "improve" the human race through controlled breeding and eliminate "poor" or "inferior" tendencies.<ref name=autogenerated103 /> By the late 1890s, [[eugenics]] programs were enjoying a "full-blown renaissance" in American prisons and institutions for the mentally ill, with leading physicians, psychologists, and wardens as proponents.<ref name=autogenerated103 /> Italian criminologist [[Cesare Lombroso]] published a highly influential tract in 1878 entitled ''L'uomo delinquente'' (or, ''The Criminal Man''), which theorized that a primitive criminal type existed who was identifiable by physical symptoms or "stigmata."<ref>Christianson, 191.</ref>
[[Phrenology]] also became a popular "science" among prison officials; at the height of the study's popularity, the influential [[Reconstruction Era]] matron of [[Sing Sing Prison]], Elizabeth W. Farnham, was one of its adherents, and officials at [[Eastern State Penitentiary]] maintained phrenological data on all inmates during the post-war years.<ref>Christianson, 191–92.</ref>
As the field of [[physical anthropology]] gained traction in the 1880s, prisons became laboratories for studying [[eugenics]], [[psychology]], [[Intelligence#Human intelligence|human intelligence]], [[medicine]], [[drug rehabilitation|drug treatment]], [[genetics]], and [[birth control]].<ref>Christianson, 192 (citing several examples).</ref> Support for these initiatives sprang from the influential prison reform organizations in the United States at the time—''e.g.'', the Prison Reform Congress, the National Conference for Charities and Corrections, the National Prison Congress, the Prison Association of New York, and the Philadelphia Society for Alleviating the Miseries of Public Prisons.<ref>Christianson, 194.</ref>
New methods of identifying criminal tendencies and classifying offenders by threat level emerged from prison-based research.<ref name=autogenerated91>Christianson, 193.</ref> In 1896, for instance, [[New York (state)|New York]] began requiring all persons sentenced to a penal institution for thirty days or more to be measured and photographed for state records.<ref name=autogenerated91 /> [[Eugenics]] studies in the prison setting led to the development of the [[vasectomy]] as a replacement for total [[castration]].<ref name="Christianson, 195">Christianson, 195.</ref>
[[Eugenics]] studies of the day aimed to prevent the extinction or genetic deterioration of mankind through restraints on reproduction, according to author Scott Christianson.<ref name=autogenerated1>Christianson, 197.</ref> In the mid-1890s, the [[Kansas]] "Home for the Feeble-Minded" began performing mass castrations on all of its residents.<ref name="Christianson, 195"/> And [[Indiana]] became the first state to enact a compulsory sterilization act for certain mentally ill and criminal persons in 1907.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[John D. Rockefeller Jr.]], a [[eugenics]] devotee, became involved in [[social Darwinism|social Darwinist]] experiments in [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /> In the 1910s, Rockefeller created the Bureau for Social Hygiene, which conducted experiments on female prisoners, with the state's consent and financial support, to determine the roots of their criminality and "mental defectiveness."<ref name=autogenerated1 />
=====Failure of Jacksonian reform and renewed efforts===== A new group of prison reformers emerged in the [[Reconstruction Era]] that maintained some optimism about the institution and initiated efforts to make the prison a center for moral [[rehabilitation (penology)|rehabilitation]]. Their efforts led to some change in contemporary prisons, but it would take another period of reform during the [[Progressive Era]] for any significant structural revisions to the prison systems of the United States.
The primary failure of [[Reconstruction Era]] penitentiaries, according to historian [[David Rothman]], was administrative. State governors typically appointed political patrons to prison posts, which were usually not full-time or salaried.<ref name="Rothman, Conscience, 25">Rothman, ''Conscience'', 25.</ref> In the 1870s, for example, the board of the [[Utica, New York]], asylum was composed of two bankers, a grain merchant, two manufacturers, two lawyers, and two general businessman.<ref name="Rothman, Conscience, 25"/> Prison oversight boards like the Utica one, composed of local businessmen, tended to defer to prison officials in most matters and focus solely on financial oversight, [[David Rothman|Rothman]] writes,<ref name=autogenerated131>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 26.</ref> and therefore tended to perpetuate the status quo.<ref name=autogenerated98>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 27.</ref>
Prison reform efforts of the [[Reconstruction Era]] came from a variety of sources. Fears about genetic contamination by the "criminal class" and its effect on the future of mankind led to numerous moral policing efforts aimed at curbing [[promiscuity]], [[prostitution]], and [[Sexual slavery|"white slavery"]] in this period.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Meanwhile, campaigns to criminalize [[domestic violence]], especially toward children, and related [[temperance movement|temperance]] movements led to renewed commitment to "law and order" in many communities from the 1870s onward.<ref name=autogenerated34>Gottschalk, 118–21.</ref> When legislators ignored demands for more protection for women and children, [[feminism|feminist]] activists lobbied for harsher punishments for male criminal offenders—including the [[Flagellation|whipping]] post, [[castration]], and longer prison terms.<ref name=autogenerated34 />
Another group of reformers continued to justify penitentiaries for negative reasons—''i.e.'', for fear that a sustained and successful attack on the prison system and its failings might yield a return to the "barbarism" of colonial-era punishments.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 28–29.</ref> Nevertheless, a degree of optimism continued to dominate the thinking of reformers in the post-Civil War period, according to historian [[David Rothman]].<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 29.</ref>
By October 1870, notable [[Reconstruction Era]] prison reformers [[Enoch Wines]], [[Franklin Sanborn]], [[Theodore William Dwight|Theodore Dwight]], and [[Zebulon Brockway]]—among others—convened with the National Congress of Penitentiary and Reformatory Discipline in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]]. The resolutions that emerged from the conference, called the ''Declaration of Principles'', became the chief planks of the [[Prison|penitentiary]] reform agenda in the United States for the next several decades.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 31; Christianson, 177</ref> The essence of the National Congress' agenda in the ''Declaration'' was a renewed commitment to the "moral regeneration" of offenders (especially young ones) through a new model of penitentiary.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 31; Christianson, 177.</ref>
The National Congress' ''Declaration of Principles'' characterized crime as "a sort of moral disease."<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 31.</ref> The ''Declaration'' stated that the "great object [of] . . . the treatment of criminals . . . should be [their] moral regeneration . . . the reformation of criminals, not the infliction of vindictive suffering."<ref>Qtd. in Rothman, ''Conscience'', 32.</ref> The Declaration took inspiration from the "Irish mark system" pioneered by [[penology|penologist]] Sir Walter Crofton. The object of Crofton's system was to teach prisoners how to lead an upright life through use of "good-time" credits (for early release) and other behavioral incentives.<ref name=autogenerated45 /> The ''Declaration'''s primary goals were: (1) to cultivate prisoners' sense of self-respect; and (2) to place the prisoner's destiny in his or her own hands.<ref name=autogenerated36>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 32.</ref> But the ''Declaration'' more broadly: * Called for [[sanitation|sanitary]] improvements and an end to the political appointment of prison administrators; * Welcomed the increased participation of women in prison management; * Advocated for a more progressive system of classifying prisoners based on individualized and continuous assessments of their character through a mark system; * Stressed the importance of educating inmates; and * Argued that prisoners' wills must be won over via persuasion, not destroyed.<ref name=autogenerated70>Christianson, 178.</ref>
The National Congress and those who responded to its agenda also hoped to implement a more open-ended sentencing code. They advocated for the replacement of the peremptory (or mandatory) sentences of the day, set by a judge after trial, with sentences of indeterminate length.<ref name=autogenerated36 /> True "proof of reformation," the Congress Declaration provided, should replace the "mere lapse of time" in winning an inmate's release from confinement.<ref name=autogenerated36 /> These suggestions anticipated the near-comprehensive adoption of indeterminate sentencing during the [[Progressive Era]].<ref>''See'' Rothman, ''Conscience'', 44, 68–70.</ref>
In spite of its many "progressive" suggestions for penal reform, the National Congress showed little sensitivity to the plight of freed blacks and immigrants in the penal system, in the view of author Scott Christianson.<ref name=autogenerated70 /> Christianson notes that the National Congress' membership generally subscribed to the prevailing contemporary notion that blacks and foreigners were disproportionately represented in the prison system due to their inherent depravity and social inferiority.<ref name=autogenerated70 />
The rise and decline of the [[Elmira Reformatory]] in [[New York (state)|New York]] during the latter part of the nineteenth century represents the most ambitious attempt in the [[Reconstruction Era]] to fulfill the goals set by the National Congress in the ''Declaration of Principles''.<ref>Christianson, 179; Rothman, ''Conscience'', 33.</ref> Built in 1876, the Elmira institution was designed to hold first-time felons, between the ages of sixteen and thirty, who were serving an indeterminate term of imprisonment set by their sentencing judge.<ref name=autogenerated62>Christianson, 179; Rothman, ''Conscience'', 33</ref> Elmira inmates had to earn their way out of the institution through good behavior, as assessed through an elaborate grading system.<ref name=autogenerated62 /> The only limits on inmates' terms of imprisonment were whatever upper threshold the legislature set for their offense.<ref>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 33.</ref>
Elmira's administration underscores the fundamental tension of contemporary penal reform, according to authors Scott Christianson and [[David Rothman]]. On the one hand, its purpose was to rehabilitate offenders; on the other, its reform principles were tempered by a belief in the heretability of criminal behavior.<ref>Christianson, 179; Rothman, ''Conscience'', 36.</ref> Elmira's first warden, National Congress member [[Zebulon Brockway]], wrote in 1884 that at least one-half of his charges were "incorrigible" due to their genetics.<ref>Christianson, 179.</ref> Brockway further characterized modern criminals as "to a considerable extent the product of our civilization and . . . of emigration to our shore from the degenerated populations of crowded European marts."<ref>Qtd. in Christianson, 180.</ref> Brockway reserved the harshest disciplinary measures—''e.g.'', frequent whippings and solitary confinement—for those he deemed "incorrigible" (primarily the mentally and physically disabled).<ref name=autogenerated23>Christianson, 181.</ref>
Elmira was regarded by many contemporaries as a well-run, model institution in its early years.<ref name=autogenerated23 /> Nevertheless, by 1893 the reformatory was seriously overcrowded and Brockway's ideas about genetic degeneracy, low-intelligence, and criminality came under fire as a result of his brutality toward the mentally and physically disabled.<ref name=autogenerated23 /> An 1894 executive investigation of Elmira's disciplinary practices concluded that discipline in the institution was harsh, although it eventually cleared Brockway of charges that he practiced "cruel, brutal, excessive, degrading and unusual punishment of inmates."<ref name="ReferenceB">Rothman, ''Conscience'', 36; Christianson, 181.</ref> But continuing stigma led the Brockway to resign from his post at Elmira by 1900.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Historian [[David Rothman]] characterizes Brockway's departure from Elmira as marking the institution's failure as a reformed penitentiary, since its methods were hardly different from those of other [[Jacksonian Era]] institutions that had survived into the post-war years. But [[David Rothman|Rothman]] also concludes that the Elmira experience suggested to contemporary reformers only that management was to blame, not their proposed system of incarceration generally.<ref name=autogenerated57>Rothman, ''Conscience'', 36.</ref> The Progressive Era of the early twentieth century thus witnessed renewed efforts to implement the penal agenda espoused by the National Congress and its adherents in 1870—albeit with some noteworthy structural additions.<ref name=autogenerated57 />
====Southern developments==== The Civil War brought overwhelming change to Southern society and its criminal justice system.<ref name="Ayers, 141"/> As freed slaves joined the Southern population, they came under the primary control of local governments for the first time.<ref name=autogenerated3>Ayers, 142.</ref> At the same time, the market economy began to affect individuals and regions in [[Southern United States|the South]] that were previously untouched.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Widespread poverty at the end of the nineteenth century unraveled the South's prior race-based social fabric.<ref name=autogenerated87>Ayers, 149.</ref> In Reconstruction-era cities like Savannah, Georgia, intricate codes of racial etiquette began to unravel almost immediately after the war with the onset of [[abolitionism in the United States|emancipation]].<ref name=autogenerated87 /> The local police forces that had been available in the antebellum South, depleted during the war, could not enforce the racial order as they had before.<ref name=autogenerated87 /> Nor was the white population, stricken by poverty and resentment, as united in its racial policing as it was during the antebellum period.<ref name=autogenerated87 /> By the end of Reconstruction, a new configuration of crime and punishment had emerged in the South: a hybrid, racialized form of incarceration at hard labor, with convicts leased to private businesses, that endured well into the twentieth century.<ref>Ayers, 142; ''see also'' Blackmon.</ref>
=====Changing demographics of crime and punishment in the Reconstruction-era South===== The economic turmoil of the post-[[American Civil War|war]] South reconstituted race relations and the nature of crime in the region, as whites attempted to reassert their supremacy. Earlier, extra-legal efforts toward reestablishing [[white supremacy]], like those of the [[Ku Klux Klan]], gradually gave way to more certain and less volatile forms of race control, according to historian [[Edward L. Ayers]].<ref>Ayers, 183</ref> Racial animosity and hatred grew as the races became ever more separate, [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] argues, and Southern legal institutions turned much of their attention to preserving the racial ''status quo'' for whites.<ref>Ayers, 183.</ref>
Patterns of "mono-racial law enforcement," as [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] refers to it, were established in Southern states almost immediately after the [[American Civil War]]. Cities that had never had [[police]] forces moved quickly to establish them,<ref>Ayers, 175–76</ref> and whites became far less critical of urban police forces in post-war politics, whereas in the antebellum period they had engendered major political debate.<ref name=autogenerated94>Ayers, 173</ref> [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah, Georgia's]] post-war police force was made up of [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] veterans, who patrolled the city in gray uniforms, armed with rifles, revolvers, and sabers.<ref name=autogenerated94 /> They were led by an ex-Confederate General, [[Richard H. Anderson]].<ref name=autogenerated94 /> [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] concludes that white policemen protecting white citizens became the model for law enforcement efforts across [[Southern United States|the South]] after the [[American Civil War]].<ref name=autogenerated94 />
Depressed economic conditions impacted both white and black farmers in the post-war South, as cotton prices entered a worldwide decline and interest rates on personal debt rose with "astonishing" speed after the close of hostilities.<ref>Ayers, 166–67.</ref> Property crime convictions in the Southern countryside, rare in the antebellum years, rose precipitously throughout the 1870s (though violent crime by white offenders continued to take up the majority of the rural courts' business).<ref>Ayers, 168—69</ref>
Former slaves who migrated to Southern cities, where they often received the lowest-paying jobs, were generally affected more acutely by economic downturns than their rural counterparts.<ref name=autogenerated110>Ayers, 172.</ref> Five years after the Civil War, 90 percent of the black population of Savannah, Georgia, owned no property.<ref name=autogenerated110 /> Increases in black property crime prosecutions in Savannah correlate to major economic downturns of the post-war period.<ref>Ayers, 172–73</ref>
Whites made few attempts to disguise the injustice in their courts, according to historian [[Edward L. Ayers]].<ref name=autogenerated73>Ayers, 184.</ref> Blacks were uniformly excluded from juries and denied any opportunity to participate in the criminal justice process aside from being defendants.<ref>Ayers, 175–76.</ref> Thefts by black offenders became a new focus of the Southern justice systems and began to supplant violent crimes by white offenders in court dockets. Whether they were from the city or the countryside, those accused of property crime stood the greatest chance of conviction in post-war southern courts.<ref name=autogenerated96>Ayers, 176</ref> But black defendants were convicted in the highest numbers. During the last half of the nineteenth century, three out of every five white defendants accused of property crime in Southern courts were convicted, while four out of every five black defendants were.<ref name=autogenerated96 /> Conviction rates for whites, meanwhile, dropped substantially from antebellum levels throughout the last half of the nineteenth century.<ref name=autogenerated41 />
This system of justice led, in the opinion of [[W.E.B. Du Bois]], to a system in which neither blacks nor whites respected the criminal justice system—whites because they were so rarely held accountable, and blacks because their own accountability felt so disproportionate.<ref>Qtd. in Ayers, 183</ref> Ultimately, thousands of black Southerners served long terms on chain gangs for petty theft and misdemeanors in the 1860s and 1870s, while thousands more went into the convict lease system.<ref name=autogenerated73 />
In criminal sentencing, blacks were disproportionately sentenced to incarceration—whether to the chain gang, convict leasing operation, or penitentiary—in relation to their white peers. Black incarceration peaked before and after [[radical Reconstruction]], when Southern whites exercised virtually unchecked power and restored "efficiency" to the criminal courts.<ref>Ayers, 169.</ref><ref>Ayers, 170.</ref> For example, 384 of [[North Carolina|North Carolina's]] 455 prisoners in 1874 were black, and in 1878 the proportion had increased slightly to 846 of 952.<ref>Christianson, 172</ref> By 1871, 609 of [[Virginia|Virginia's]] 828 convicts in—including all but four of its sixty-seven female prisoners—were black.<ref>Christianson, 173</ref> But this phenomenon was not specific to the South: The proportion of black inmates in Northern prisons was virtually identical to that in Southern prisons throughout the second half of the nineteenth century.<ref>Ayers, 170</ref>
Rural courts met so rarely in the post-war years that prisoners often sat in jails for months while awaiting trial, at the government's expense.<ref name=autogenerated20>Ayers, 177.</ref> [[Chain gang]]s emerged in the post-war years as an initial solution to this economic deficit.<ref name=autogenerated20 /> Urban and rural counties moved the locus of criminal punishment from municipalities and towns to the county and began to change the economics of punishment from a heavy expense to a source of public "revenue"—at least in terms of infrastructure improvements.<ref name=autogenerated20 /> Even misdemeanors could be turned to economic advantage; defendants were often sentenced to only a few on the chain gang, with an additional three to eight months tacked onto the sentence to cover "costs."<ref>Ayers, 178.</ref> As the Southern economy foundered in the wake of the peculiar institution's destruction, and property crime rose, state governments increasingly explored the economic potential of convict labor throughout the Reconstruction period and into the twentieth century.<ref>Ayers, 182–85.</ref>
=====Institutional power struggles over the Southern justice apparatus===== "The most far-reaching change in the history of crime and punishment in the nineteenth-century South," according to historian [[Edward L. Ayers]], was "the state's assumption of control over blacks from their ex-masters . . . ."<ref>Ayers 150.</ref> The process by which this occurred was "halting and tenuous," but the transition began the moment a master told his slaves they were free."<ref>Ayers, 150.</ref> In this landscape, Ayers writes, the [[Freedmen's Bureau]] vied with Southern whites—through official government apparatuses and informal organizations like the [[Ku Klux Klan]]—over opposing notions of justice in the post-war [[Southern United States|South]].<ref name=autogenerated22>Ayers, 151.</ref>
Southern whites in the main tried to salvage as much of the antebellum order as possible in the wake of the [[American Civil War]], waiting to see what changes might be forced upon them.<ref name=autogenerated22 /> The [[Black Codes (United States)|"Black Codes"]] enacted almost immediately after the war—[[Mississippi]] and [[South Carolina]] passed theirs as early as 1865—were an initial effort in this direction.<ref name=autogenerated22 /> Although they did not use racial terms, the Codes defined and punished a new crime, "vagrancy," broadly enough to guarantee that most newly free black Americans would remain in a ''de facto'' condition of servitude.<ref name=autogenerated22 /> The Codes vested considerable discretion in local judges and juries to carry out this mission: County courts could choose lengths and types of punishment previously unavailable.<ref name=autogenerated22 /> The available punishments for vagrancy, arson, rape, and burglary in particular—thought by whites to be peculiarly black crimes—widened considerably in the post-war years.<ref name=autogenerated22 />
Soon after hostilities officially ceased between the [[United States]] and the [[Confederate States of America]], black "vagrants" in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], were being fined and sent to the city workhouse.<ref>Christianson, 171.</ref> In [[San Antonio, Texas]], and [[Montgomery, Alabama]], free blacks were arrested, imprisoned, and put to work on the streets to pay for their own upkeep.<ref name=autogenerated119>Christianson, 172.</ref> A Northern journalist who passed through [[Selma, Alabama]], immediately after of the [[American Civil War|war]], was told that no white man had ever been sentenced to the [[chain gang]], but that blacks were now being condemned to it for such "crimes" as "using abusive language towards a white man" or selling farm produce within the town limits.<ref>Qtd. in Christianson, 171.</ref>
At the same time that [[Reconstruction Era]] [[Southern United States|Southern]] governments enacted the [[Black Codes (United States)|"Black Codes"]], they also began to change the nature of the state's penal machinery to make it into an economic development tool.<ref>Christianson, 172; Gottschalk, 47–52</ref> Social historian Marie Gottschalk characterizes the use of penal labor by Southern state governments during the post-[[American Civil War|war]] years as an "important bridge between an agricultural economy based on slavery and the industrialization and agricultural modernization of the New South."<ref name="Gottschalk, 49">Gottschalk, 49.</ref>
Many prisons in [[Southern United States|the South]] were in a state of disrepair by the end of the [[American Civil War]], and state budgets across the region were exhausted.<ref name=autogenerated119 /> [[Mississippi|Mississippi's]] [[Prison|penitentiary]], for instance, was devastated during the war, and its funds depleted. In 1867 the state's military government began leasing convicts to rebuild wrecked [[railroad]] and [[levee]]s within the state. By 1872, it began leasing convicts to [[Nathan Bedford Forrest]], a former [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] general and [[slave trader]], as well as the first [[Imperial Wizard]] of the then emerging [[Ku Klux Klan]].<ref>Christianson, 172 – 73</ref>
[[Texas]] also experienced a major postwar depression, in the midst of which its legislators enacted tough new laws calling for forced inmate labor within prison walls and at other works of public utility outside of the state's detention facilities.<ref>Christianson, 174</ref> Soon Texas began leasing convicts to railroads, [[irrigation]] and navigation projects, and [[lead]], [[copper]], and [[iron]] mines.<ref>Christianson, 174.</ref>
[[Virginia]]'s prison at [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] collapsed in the wake of the City's 1865 surrender, but occupying [[Union Army|Union forces]] rounded up as many convicts as they could in order to return them to work.<ref>Christianson, 173.</ref> [[Alabama]] began leasing out its [[Wetumpka Prison]] to private businessmen soon after the Civil War.<ref name=autogenerated119 />
During the [[Reconstruction Era]], the [[North Carolina]] legislature authorized state judges to sentence offenders to work on [[chain gang]]s on county roads, railroads, or other internal improvements for a maximum term of one year—though escapees who were recaptured would have to serve double their original sentence.<ref name=autogenerated119 /> North Carolina had failed to erect a penitentiary in the antebellum period, and its legislators planned to build an [[Auburn Prison|Auburn]]-style penitentiary to replace the penal labor system.<ref name=autogenerated119 /> But graft and shady dealings soon rendered a new prison impracticable, and North Carolina convicts continued to be leased to railroad companies.<ref name=autogenerated119 />
Freed blacks became the primary workers in the South's emerging penal labor system. Those accused of property crime—white or black—stood the greatest chance of conviction in post-war Southern courts.<ref name=autogenerated41>Ayers, 179.</ref> But black property offenders were convicted more often than white ones—at a rate of eight convictions for every ten black defendants, compared to six of every ten white defendants.<ref>Ayers, 176.</ref> Overall, conviction rates for whites dropped substantially from antebellum levels during the [[Reconstruction Era]] and continued to decline throughout the last half of the nineteenth century.<ref name=autogenerated41 />
The [[Freedmen's Bureau]], charged with implementing congressional reconstruction throughout the former Confederate states, was the primary political body that opposed the increasing racial overtones of Southern criminal justice during the [[Reconstruction Era]].<ref name=autogenerated71>Ayers, 152.</ref> The Bureau's mission reflected a strong faith in impersonal legalism, according to historian [[Edward L. Ayers]], and its agents were to act as guarantors of blacks' legal equality.<ref name=autogenerated71 /> The Bureau maintained courts in the South from 1865 to 1868 to adjudicate minor civil and criminal cases involving freed slaves.<ref name=autogenerated71 /> Ultimately, [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] concludes, the [[Freedmen's Bureau|Bureau]] largely failed to protect freed slaves from crime and violence by whites, or from the injustices of the Southern legal system, although the Bureau did provide much needed services to freed slaves in the form of food, clothing, school support, and assistance in contracts.<ref name="Ayers, 155">Ayers, 155.</ref> The [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] ''Herald'' more bluntly stated that the [[Freedmen's Bureau]] was no match for the "Organic Law of the Land" in the South, white supremacy.<ref>Qtd. in Ayers, 155.</ref>
In the rural [[Southern United States|South]], the [[Freedmen's Bureau]] was only as strong as its isolated agents, who were often unable to assert their will over that of the whites in their jurisdiction.<ref>Ayers 154.</ref> Manpower issues and local white resentment led to early compromises under which southern civilians were allowed to serve as [[magistrate]]s on the Freedmen's Courts, although the move was opposed by many former slaves.<ref name=autogenerated71 />
In cities like [[Savannah, Georgia]], the Freedmen's Courts appeared even more disposed to enforcing the wishes of local whites, sentencing former slaves (and veterans of the [[Union Army]]) to [[chain gang]]s, [[corporal punishment]]s, and public shaming.<ref name=autogenerated116>Ayers, 154.</ref> The Savannah Freedmen's Courts even approved arrests for such "offenses" as "shouting at a religious colored meeting," or speaking disrespectfully to a white man.<ref name=autogenerated116 />
The Bureau's influence on post-war patterns of crime and punishment was temporary and limited.<ref name="Ayers, 164">Ayers, 164.</ref> The United States Congress believed that only its unprecedented federal intrusion into state affairs through the Bureau could bring true republicanism to the South, according to [[Edward L. Ayers]], but Southerners instinctively resented this as a grave violation of their own republican ideals.<ref name="Ayers, 164"/> Southerners had always tended to circumscribe the sphere of written, institutionalized law, [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] argues, and once they began to associate it with outside oppression from the federal government, they saw little reason to respect it at all.<ref>Ayers, 155–56.</ref> From this resentment, vigilante groups like the [[Ku Klux Klan]] arose in opposition to the [[Freedmen's Bureau|Bureau]] and its mission—though, in the words of [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]], the Klan was a "relatively brief episode in a long history of post-war group violence in the South," where extralegal retribution was and continued to be a tradition.<ref>Ayers, 156.</ref>
For their part, former slaves in the Reconstruction-era South made efforts of their own to counteract white supremacist violence and injustice. In March 1866, Abraham Winfield and ten other black men petitioned the head of the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] [[Freedmen's Bureau]] for relief from the oppression of the Bureau's Court in [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah]]—especially for [[American Civil War|Civil War]] veterans.<ref name="Ayers, 155"/> In rural areas like [[Greene County, Georgia]], blacks met [[vigilante]] violence from whites with violence of their own.<ref>Ayers, 157.</ref> But with the withdrawal of the [[Freedmen's Bureau]] in 1868 and continuing political violence from whites, blacks ultimately lost this struggle, according to historian [[Edward L. Ayers]].<ref name=autogenerated35>Ayers, 158.</ref> Southern courts were largely unable—even they were willing—to bring whites to justice for violence against black Southerners.<ref>Ayers, 160.</ref> By the early to mid-1870s, white political supremacy had been established anew across most of the South.<ref name=autogenerated35 />
In Southern cities, a different form of violence emerged in the post-[[American Civil War|war]] years. Race riots erupted in Southern cities almost immediately after the war and continued for years afterward. Edward L. Ayers concludes that antebellum legal restraints on blacks and widespread poverty were the primary cause of many of these clashes.<ref>Ayers, 161.</ref> Whites resented labor competition from blacks in the depressed post-war Southern economy, and police forces—many composed of unreconstructed Southerners—often resorted to violence. The ultimate goal for both blacks and whites was to obtain political power in the vacuum created by war and emancipation; again, blacks ultimately lost this struggle during the Reconstruction period.<ref>Ayers, 161–62</ref>
=====Beginning of the convict lease system===== Convict leasing, practiced in the North from the earliest days of the penitentiary movement, was taken up by Southern states in earnest following the [[American Civil War]].<ref name=autogenerated89>Christianson, 183.</ref> The use of convict labor remained popular nationwide throughout the post-war period.<ref name="autogenerated89"/> An 1885 national survey reported that 138 institutions employed over 53,000 inmates in industries, who produced goods valued at $28.8 million.<ref name=autogenerated39>Christianson, 187</ref> Although this was a relatively small sum in comparison to the estimated $5.4 billion in goods produced by free labor in 1880, prison labor was big business for those involved in particular industries.<ref name=autogenerated39 />
But convict leasing in the post-war South came to play a more central role in crime and punishment than in the North, and it continued to do so with the approbation of the South's leading men until well into the twentieth century.<ref>Christianson, 186; ''see also generally'' Blackmon.</ref> For over a half-century following the Civil War, convict camps dotted the Southern landscape, and thousands of men and women—most of them former slaves—passed years of their lives within the system.<ref name=autogenerated84>Christianson, 186.</ref> Men with capital, from the North and the South, bought years of these convicts' lives and put them to work in large mining and railroad operations, as well as smaller everyday businesses.<ref name=autogenerated84 /> On average, the death rate in Southern leasing arrangements exceeded that in Northern prisons three-fold.<ref>Christianson, 182.</ref>
The convict lease, as practiced in the South, was not just a bald attempt by state governments to resurrect slavery, according to historians [[Edward L. Ayers]] and Marie Gottschalk. It reflected continuities in race relations, both argue, but it also reflected fundamental changes in the post-war Southern economy.<ref name="Ayers, 185; Gottschalk, 47–52">Ayers, 185; Gottschalk, 47–52.</ref> For first time, millions of freed slaves came under the centralized control of state penal apparatuses; at the same time, nascent industrial capitalism in the South faced a shortage of both capital and labor.<ref>Ayers, 185; ''see also'' Gottschalk, 47–52.</ref> Former slaves were the easiest Southern demographic to impress into service and adapt southern industries to these changes.<ref>Ayers, 185.</ref>
Ultimately, however, the longest legacy of the system may be as symbol for white South's injustice and inhumanity.<ref name=autogenerated140>Ayers, 186.</ref> In 1912, Dr. E. Stagg of the National Commission on Prison Labor described the status of the Southern convict as "the last surviving vestige of the slave system."<ref>Christianson, 182</ref> A Northern writer in the 1920s referred to the Southern [[chain gang]] as the South's new "[[peculiar institution]]".<ref>Qtd. in Christianson, 182.</ref>
Southern penitentiaries from the antebellum period by and large continued to fall into disrepair in the post-war years as they became mere outposts of the much larger convict labor system.<ref name=autogenerated140 /> One by one, Southern penitentiary systems had disintegrated during the [[American Civil War]]. [[Mississippi]] sent its prisoners to [[Alabama]] for safekeeping in the midst of a Northern invasion.<ref name=autogenerated140 /> [[Louisiana]] concentrated its prisoners into a single urban workhouse.<ref name=autogenerated140 /> [[Arkansas]] dispersed its convicts in 1863 when the [[Union Army]] breached its borders.<ref name=autogenerated140 /> Occupied [[Tennessee]] hired its prisoners out to the [[United States]] government, while [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] freed its inmates as General [[William Tecumseh Sherman]] headed for [[Atlanta Campaign|Atlanta]] with his armies in 1864.<ref name=autogenerated140 /> With the fall of [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], most of [[Virginia|Virginia's]] prisoners escaped.<ref name=autogenerated140 />
The convict lease system emerged haltingly from this chaos, [[Edward L. Ayers]] and Marie Gottschalk conclude, just as the penitentiary itself had in years past.<ref name="Ayers, 185; Gottschalk, 47–52"/> The penitentiary had become a Southern institution at this point, [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] points out, and its complete abolition would have required a major renovation of state criminal codes.<ref name=autogenerated95>Ayers, 188.</ref> Some states, like [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], tried to revive their penitentiary systems in the post-war years, but had to first deal with crumbling state infrastructure and a growing prison population.<ref name=autogenerated95 /> The three states that had not established prisons in the antebellum period—''i.e.'', the Carolinas and Florida—hastened to establish them during [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]].<ref>Ayers, 188–89.</ref>
But many Southern states—including [[North Carolina]], [[Mississippi]], [[Virginia]], and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]—soon turned to the lease system as a temporary expedient, as rising costs and convict populations outstripped their meager resources.<ref name=autogenerated37>Ayers, 189; Gottschalk, 47–52.</ref> According to [[Edward L. Ayers]], "[t]he South . . . more or less stumbled into the lease, seeking a way to avoid large expenditures while hoping a truly satisfactory plan would emerge."<ref name=autogenerated37 /> Social historian Marie Gottschalk characterizes these leasing arrangements as an "important bridge between an agricultural economy based on slavery and the industrialization and agricultural modernization of the New South."<ref name="Gottschalk, 49"/> This may help to explain why support for the convict lease was altogether widespread in Southern society, [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] concludes. No single group—black or white, [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] or [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]—consistently opposed the lease once it gained power.<ref>Ayers, 190.</ref>
The labor that convict lessees performed varied as the Southern economy evolved after the [[American Civil War]].<ref>Ayers, 191.</ref> Ex-plantation owners were early beneficiaries, but emerging industrial capitalism ventures—''e.g.'', [[phosphate]] mines and [[turpentine]] plants in [[Florida]], railroads in [[Mississippi]] (and across the South)—soon came to demand convict labor.<ref>Ayers, 192–93</ref> The South experienced an acute labor shortage in the post-war years, [[Edward L. Ayers]] explains, and no pool of displaced agricultural laborers was available to feed the needs of factory owners, as they had been in England and on the Continent.<ref>Ayers, 192.</ref>
The lease system was useful for capitalists who wanted to make money quickly: Labor costs were fixed and low, and labor uncertainty was reduced to the vanishing point.<ref name=autogenerated76>Ayers, 193.</ref> Convicts could be and were driven to a point free laborers would not tolerate (and could not drink or misbehave).<ref name=autogenerated76 /> Although labor unrest and economic depression continued to rile the North and its factories, the lease system insulated its beneficiaries in South from these external costs.<ref>Ayers, 193–94.</ref>
In many cases, [[Edward L. Ayers]] writes, the businessmen who utilized the convict-lease system were the same politicians who administered it. The system became, [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] argues, a sort of "mutual aid society" for the new breed of capitalists and politicians who controlled the white Democratic regimes of the [[New South]].<ref>Ayers, 195.</ref> Thus, [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]] concludes, officials often had something to hide, and contemporary reports on leasing operations often skirted or ignored the appalling conditions and death rates that attended these projects.<ref>Ayers, 196.</ref>
In Alabama, 40 percent of convict lessees died during their term of labor in 1870—death rates for 1868 and 1869 were 18 and 17 percent, respectively.<ref name=autogenerated66>Ayers, 201.</ref> Lessees on Mississippi's convict labor projects died at nine times the rate of inmates in Northern prisons throughout the 1880s.<ref name=autogenerated66 /> One man who had served time in the Mississippi system claimed that reported death rates would have been far higher had the state not pardoned many broken convicts before they died, so that they could do so at home instead.<ref>Qtd. in Ayers, 201.</ref>
Compared to contemporary non-leasing prison systems nationwide, which recouped only 32 percent of expenses on average, convict leasing systems earned average profits of 267 percent.<ref name=autogenerated101>Ayers, 197.</ref> Even in comparison to Northern factories, [[Edward L. Ayers]] writes, the lease system's profitability was real and sustained in the post-war years and remained so into the twentieth century.<ref name=autogenerated101 />
Exposes on the lease system began appearing with increasing frequency in newspapers, state documents, Northern publications, and the publications of national prison associations during the post-war period—just as they did for Northern prisons like those in [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref name=autogenerated101 /> Mass grave sites containing the remains of convict lessees have been discovered in Southern states like [[Alabama]], where the [[United States Steel Corporation]] purchased convict labor for its mining operations for several years at the end of the nineteenth and beginning of the twentieth centuries.<ref>Blackmon, 3.</ref>
The focus of Southern justice on racial control in the post-war years had a profound effect on the demographics of the lease systems' populations. Before the Civil War, virtually all Southern prisoners were white, but under post-war leasing arrangements almost all (approximately 90 percent) were black.<ref name=autogenerated101 /> In the antebellum period, white immigrants made up a disproportionate share of the South's prison population before all but disappearing from prison records in the post-war period.<ref name=autogenerated101 /> The reasons for this are likely two-fold, [[Edward L. Ayers]] suggests. First, white immigrants generally avoided the post-war South due to its generally poor economic climate and the major increase in labor competition posed by emancipated slaves.<ref>Ayers, 197–98</ref> Second, the preoccupation of post-war Southern police forces with crime committed by blacks decreased their efforts among the white population, including immigrants.<ref name=autogenerated134>Ayers, 198.</ref>
The source of convicts also changed in the post-war South. Before the [[American Civil War]], rural counties sent few defendants to the state penitentiaries, but after the war rural courts became steady suppliers to their states' leasing systems (though cities remained the largest supplier of convict lessees during this period).<ref name=autogenerated101 /> [[Savannah, Georgia]], for example, sent convicts to leasing operations at approximately three times the number that its population would suggest, a pattern amplified by the reality that 76 percent of all blacks convicted in its courts received a prison sentence.<ref name=autogenerated101 />
Most convicts were in their twenties or younger.<ref name=autogenerated32>Ayers, 199.</ref> The number of women in Southern prison systems, increased in the post-war years to about 7 percent, a ratio not incommensurate with other contemporary prisons in the United States, but a major increase for the South, which had previously boasted of the moral rectitude of its (white) female population.<ref name=autogenerated16>Ayers, 200.</ref> Virtually all such women were black.<ref name=autogenerated16 />
The officials who ran the South's leasing operations tried to maintain strict racial separation in the convict camps, refusing to recognize social equality between the races even among felons.<ref name=autogenerated134 /> As one Southerner reported to the National Prison Congress in 1886: Mixing the races in prison "is akin to the torture anciently practised of tieing [''sic''] a murderer to the dead body of his victim limb to limb, from head to foot, until the decaying corpse brought death to the living."<ref>Qtd. in Ayers, 198.</ref> Whites who did end up in Southern prisons, according to [[Edward L. Ayers]], were considered the lowest of their race. At least some legislators referred to white prisoners with the same [[racial epithets]] reserved for blacks at the time.<ref name=autogenerated134 />
The Southern lease system was something less than a "total system."<ref name=autogenerated66 /> The vast majority of convict-lease camps were dispersed, with little in the way of walls or other securities measures<ref name=autogenerated141>Ayers, 203.</ref>—although some Southern chain gangs were carted around in open-air cages to their work sites and kept in them at night.<ref>Ayers, 181; ''see also generally'' Blackmon.</ref> Order in the camps was generally tenuous at best, [[Edward L. Ayers]] argues. Escapes were frequent and the brutal punishments that characterized the camps—chains, bloodhounds, guns, and corporal punishments—were dealt with a palpable sense of desperation.<ref name=autogenerated66 /> (At least some observers, however, questioned whether the high number of reported escapees was not a ploy to cover up foul play.)<ref>Ayers, 201; Christianson, 182.</ref>
Reflecting changing criminal dockets in the Southern courts, about half of prisoners in the lease system served sentences for property crime.<ref name=autogenerated141 /> Rehabilitation played no real role in the system. Whatever onus for reform there was fell on the shoulders of chaplains, [[Edward L. Ayers]] relates.<ref>Ayers, 207.</ref> As Warden J.H. Bankhead of the [[Alabama]] penitentiary observed in the 1870s: "[O]ur system is a better training school for criminals than any of the dens of iniquity that exist in our large cities. . . . You may as well expect to instill decent habits into a hog as to reform a criminal whose habits and surroundings are as filthy as a pig's." <ref name=autogenerated23 />
Some proponents of the lease claimed that the system would teach blacks to work, but many contemporary observers came to recognize—as historian [[C. Vann Woodward]] later would—that the system dealt a great blow to whatever moral authority white society had retained in its paternalistic approach to the "race problem."<ref>Ayers, 208–09</ref> Time in the penitentiary came to carry little stigma in the black community, as preachers and other community leaders spread word of its cruelty.<ref name=autogenerated77>Ayers, 211.</ref>
Whites presented far from a united front in defense of the lease system during the [[Reconstruction Era]].<ref name=autogenerated77 /> Reformers and government insiders began condemning the worst abuses of the system from early on. Newspapers began taking up the call by the 1880s, although they had defended it during the more politically charged years that immediately followed the Civil War.<ref>Ayers, 218.</ref> But the system also had its defenders—at times even the reformers themselves, who chafed at Northern criticism even where they agreed with its substance.<ref>Ayers, 219.</ref> The"scientific" racial attitudes of the late nineteenth century also helped some supporters of the lease to assuage their misgivings. One commentator wrote that blacks died in such numbers on the convict lease farms because of the weakness of their inferior, "uneducated" blood.<ref>Ayers, 220.</ref>
Economic, rather than moral, concerns underlay the more successful attacks on leasing. Labor launched effective opposition movements to the lease in the post-war period.<ref name=autogenerated77 /> [[Birmingham, Alabama]], and its Anti-Convict League, formed in 1885, were the center of this movement, according to [[Edward L. Ayers|Ayers]].<ref>Ayers, 214.</ref> Coal miner revolts against the lease occurred twenty-two recorded times in the South between 1881 and 1900.<ref name=autogenerated63>Ayers, 216.</ref> By 1895, [[Tennessee]] caved in to the demands of its miners and abolished its lease system.<ref>Ayers, 215.</ref> These revolts notably crossed racial lines. In [[Alabama]], for instance, white and black free miners marched side-by-side to protest the use of convict labor in local mining operations.<ref name=autogenerated63 />
In these confrontations, convict labor surely took on a somewhat exaggerated importance to free workers, argues [[Edward L. Ayers]]. Only 27,000 convicts were engaged in some form of labor arrangement in the 1890s South.<ref name=autogenerated139>Ayers, 213.</ref> But the emerging nature of Southern industry and labor groups—which tended to be smaller and more concentrated—made for a situation in which a small number of convicts could affect entire industries.<ref name=autogenerated139 />
===Progressive era===
====Southern developments====
=====Gradual demise of the convict lease===== Just as the convict lease emerged gradually in the post-war South, it also made a gradual exit.
Although [[Virginia]], [[Texas]], [[Tennessee]], [[Kentucky]], and [[Missouri]] utilized Northern-style manufacturing prisons in addition to their farms, as late as 1890 the majority of Southern convicts still passed their sentences in convict camps run by absentee businessmen.<ref name=autogenerated113>Ayers, 221.</ref> But the 1890s also marked the beginning of a gradual shift toward compromise over the lease system, in the form of state-run prison farms.<ref name=autogenerated113 /> States began to cull the women, children, and the sick from the old privately run camps during this period, to remove them from the "contamination" of bad criminals and provide a healthier setting and labor regime.<ref name=autogenerated113 /> [[Mississippi]] enacted a new state constitution in 1890 that called for the end of the lease by 1894.<ref name=autogenerated113 />
Despite these changes, and continuing attacks from labor movements, [[Populism|Populists]], and [[Greenback Party|Greenbackers]], only two Southern states besides [[Mississippi]] ended the system prior to the twentieth century.<ref name=autogenerated113 /> Most Southern states did bring their systems under tighter control and make increasing use of state penal farms by the twentieth century, however, resulting in improved conditions and a decline in death rates.<ref name=autogenerated133>Ayers, 222.</ref> [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] abolished its system in 1908, after an expose by [[Charles Edward Russell]] in ''[[Everybody's Magazine]]'' revealed "hideous" conditions on lease projects.<ref name=autogenerated89 /> A former warden described how men in the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] camps were hung by their thumbs as punishment, to the point that their thumbs became so stretched and deformed, to the length of index fingers, that they resembled the "paws of certain apes."<ref name=autogenerated89 /> Florida's prison camps—where even the sick were forced to work under threat of a beating or shooting—remained in use until 1923.<ref name=autogenerated89 />
Replacements for the lease system, such as [[chain gang]]s and state prison farms, were not so different from their predecessors.<ref name=autogenerated133 /> An example of the lingering influence of the lease system can be found in the Arkansas prison farms. By the mid-twentieth century, Arkansas' male penal system still consisted of two large prison farms, which remained almost totally cut off from the outside world and continued to operate much as they had during the [[Reconstruction Era]].<ref name=autogenerated67>Christianson, 258.</ref> Conditions in these camps were bad enough that, as late as the 1960s, an [[Oregon]] judge refused to return escapees from [[Arkansas]], who had been apprehended in his jurisdiction.<ref>Christianson, 262.</ref> The judge declared that returning the prisoners to [[Arkansas]] would make his state complicit in what he described as "institutes of terror, horror, and despicable evil," which he compared to [[Nazi]] [[concentration camp]]s.<ref>Ayers, 262.</ref>
In 1966, around the time of the [[Oregon]] judge's ruling, the ratio of staff to inmates at the Arkansas penal farms was one staff member for every sixty-five inmates.<ref name=autogenerated67 /> By contrast, the national average at the time was around one prison staff member for every seven inmates.<ref name=autogenerated67 /> The state was not the only entity profiting from the farm; private operators controlled certain of its industries and maintained high profit margins.<ref name="Christianson, 261">Christianson, 261.</ref> The physician who ran the farm's for-profit blood bank, for instance, earned between $130,000 and $150,000 per year off of inmate donations that he sold to hospitals.<ref name="Christianson, 261"/>
Faced with this acute shortage of manpower, authorities at the penal farms relied upon armed inmates, known as "trusties" or "riders," to guard the convicts while they worked<ref name=autogenerated67 /> Under the trusties' control prisoners worked ten to fourteen hours per day (depending on the time of year), six days per week.<ref name=autogenerated67 /> Arkansas was, at the time, the only state where prison officials could still whip convicts.<ref name=autogenerated67 />
Violent deaths were commonplace on the Arkansas prison farms.<ref name=autogenerated81>Christianson, 259.</ref> An investigation begun by incumbent Governor [[Orval Faubus]] during a heated 1966 gubernatorial race revealed ongoing abuses—''e.g.'', use of wire pliers on inmates' genitals, stabbings, use of nut crackers to break inmates knuckles, trampling of inmates with horses, and charging inmates for hospital time after beatings.<ref name=autogenerated81 /> When the chairman of the Arkansas legislature's prison committee was asked about the allegations, however, he replied, "Arkansas has the best prison system in the United States."<ref>Qtd. in Christianson, 259.</ref> Only later, after a federal court intervened, did reforms begin at the Arkansas prison camps.<ref>Christianson, 260–64.</ref>
