Sloat named Stockton commander-in-chief of all land forces in California.<ref>Walker p. 151, 154</ref> |- |July 16, 1846||Fremont raised the U.S. flag over San Juan Bautista.<ref name="Walker p. 149"/> |- |July 16, 1846||Governor Pico issued a proclamation on the American invasion and a conscription order for Mexican citizens, which produced about 100 men to join with Castro's force.<ref>Walker p. 155-156</ref> |- |July 19, 1846||Fremont's party entered Monterey. Fremont met with Sloat on board the ''Savannah''. When Sloat learned that Fremont had acted on his own authority, he retired to his cabin.<ref>Walker p. 149-151</ref> |- |July 23, 1846||Stockton mustered Fremont's party and the former Bear Flaggers into military service as the "Naval Battalion of Mounted Volunteer Riflemen" with Fremont in command.<ref>Walker p. 154</ref> |- |July 26, 1846||Stockton ordered Fremont and his battalion to San Diego to prepare to move northward to Los Angeles.<ref>Walker p. 156</ref> |- |July 29, 1846||Sloat ordered the release of Vallejo and the other prisoners at Sutter's Fort. Sloat turned command over to Stockton and left for home. Stockton issued a proclamation annexing California to the U.S. General Castro in Santa Clara subsequently began to move south to Los Angeles with about 100 men.<ref>Walker p. 154-155</ref> |- |July 29, 1846||The battalion landed and raised the U.S. flag in San Diego.<ref name="Walker p. 157">Walker p. 157</ref> |- |end Jul-1846||A garrison of Stockton's men raised the U.S. flag at Santa Barbara.<ref name="Walker p. 157"/> |- |August 1, 1846||An ill and much thinner Vallejo was released from Sutter's Fort. While in confinement, 1000 of his cattle and 600 horses were stolen.<ref>Walker p. 127</ref> |- |August 1, 1846||Stockton's 360 men arrived in San Pedro.<ref name="Walker p. 157"/> |- |August 2, 1846||Two representatives of Castro arrived at Stockton's camp with a message expressing Castro's willingness to negotiate for peace. Stockton rejected the terms of the letter.<ref name="Walker p. 157"/> |- |August 7, 1846||Stockton penned a return message to Castro, who also rejected its terms, including that California cease to be part of Mexico.<ref name="Walker p. 157"/> |- |August 9, 1846||Castro held a war council at La Mesa, expressed doubts about his forces, and wrote a farewell address to the people of California. Governor Pico read Castro's message to the legislature in Los Angeles, which then adjourned ''sine die''. Pico penned an open farewell letter.<ref>Walker p. 158</ref> |- |August 10, 1846||Castro and 20 men rode toward the Colorado River and reached the Mexican state of Sonora in September. Pico left to hide out in San Juan Capistrano for one month and eventually made his way to Baja California and Sonora.<ref name="Walker p. 159">Walker p. 159</ref> |- |August 13, 1846||Stockton's army entered Los Angeles unopposed.<ref name="Walker p. 159"/> |- |August 17, 1846||Stockton issued a proclamation announcing that California was now part of the United States.<ref name="Walker p. 159"/> |- |August 22, 1846||Stockton sent a report to Secretary of State Bancroft that "California is entirely free from Mexican dominion."<ref>Walker p. 160</ref> </onlyinclude> |}

page.title: List of worker deaths in United States labor disputes

revision.comment: removed parent category and grandparent category of [[Category:Labor disputes]]
revision.text:
The following '''list of worker deaths in United States labor disputes''' captures known incidents of fatal labor-related violence in U.S. labor history, which began in the colonial era with the [[Timeline of labor issues and events|earliest worker demands]] around 1636 for better working conditions. According to a study in 1969, the United States has had the bloodiest and most violent labor history of any industrial nation in the world, and there have been few industries which have been immune.<ref>Philip Taft and Philip Ross, "American Labor Violence: Its Causes, Character, and Outcome," The History of Violence in America: A Report to the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence, ed. Hugh Davis Graham and Ted Robert Gurr, 1969.</ref>
This list is not comprehensive. A number of factors (multi-sided conflicts, physically remote locations, company-controlled locations, exaggerated or biased original reporting, etc.) make some of the death and injury counts uncertain.
==By authorities==
===Law enforcement and companies' militia, armed detectives and guards=== :{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; font-size:87%; border:1; cellpadding:5; cellspacing:0;" !scope="col" data-sort-type="date"|Date !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Industry !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Type of dispute !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Workers violently killed by authorities !scope="col" class="unsortable" |Notes |---- |August 8, 1850 |Manhattan, NYC, NY | style="text-align: center;"|garment | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |At least two tailors died as police confronted a street mob of about 300 strikers, mostly German, with clubs.<ref>Chants Democratic: New York City and the Rise of the American Working Class, by Sean Wilentz, 2004, pages 380-381, citing the [[New York Herald]] for August 6 and 7, 1850, and the [[New York Tribune]] for August 5 and 6, 1850</ref> These deaths stand as the “first recorded strike fatalities in U.S. history”.<ref>Civil War America, 1850 to 1875, by Richard F. Selcer, 2014, page 88</ref> |---- |July 7, 1851 |Portage, NY | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Two striking workers of the New York and Erie Railroad were shot and killed by police officers. Strikers were dispersed the following morning by the state militia.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zKkWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA449&lpg=PA449&dq=portage+%22new+york%22+railroad+strike+1851&source=bl&ots=J-FlFb1YbB&sig=cFXhnhs1xXnCrdgc7u1nyN3SLoM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEwQ6AEwCWoVChMI6cXHvtX_xwIVEgaSCh1-pQ1G#v=onepage&q=portage%20%22new%20york%22%20railroad%20strike%201851&f=false |title=A History of Livingston County, New York: From Its Earliest Traditions, to Its Part in the War for Our Union: with an Account of the Seneca Nation of Indians, and Biographical Sketches of Earliest Settlers and Prominent Public Men|first=Lockwood Lyon|last=Doty|publisher=Edward L. Doty|year=1876|pages=449–450}}</ref> |--- |May 17, 1871 |Hyde Park section of Scranton, PA | style="text-align: center;"|coal | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Two strikers, Benjamin Davis and Daniel Jones,<ref>''Scranton Republican'', Saturday, September 30, 1916, page 43, partially visible online at https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/48843322/</ref> were shot and killed by a single bullet fired in Scranton during the 1871 [[Workingmen's Benevolent Association of Schuylkill County|Workingmen's Benevolent Association]] union coal strike. The shot was fired under the command of William W. Scranton.{{dubious| The source says the shot was fired by a non-striking worker, possibly in self-defense.|date=April 2016}} Eight thousand people attended the strikers' funeral.<ref>“Imposing Demonstration at the Two Miners’ Funeral.” New York Times, May 19, 1871</ref> |---- |July 20, 1877 |Baltimore, MD | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|10 |During the [[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]], first national strike in United States, National Guard regiments were ordered to [[Cumberland, Maryland]], to face strikers. As they marched toward their train in Baltimore, violent street battles between the striking workers and the guardsmen erupted. Troops fired on the crowd, killing 10 and wounding 25.<ref name="scharf">{{Cite book|last=Scharf|first=J. Thomas|title=History of Maryland From the Earliest Period to the Present Day: 1819-1880|publisher=John B. Piet |date=1879|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XnsjAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=bibliogroup:%22History+of+Maryland+from+the+Earliest+Period+to+the+Present+Day%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwBWoVChMI7cPH3OP1xwIVT1GICh3p-gfx#v=onepage&q&f=false |location = Baltimore, Maryland|pages=732–42 }}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 21, 1877"|July 21–22, 1877 |Pittsburgh, PA | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|40 |[[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]: As militiamen approached and sought to protect the roundhouse, they bayoneted and fired on rock-throwing strikers, killing 20 people and wounding 29.<ref name="UE">{{cite web |last= |first= |title=The Great Strike of 1877: Remembering a Worker Rebellion|work= |publisher=UE News|date=June 2002|url=http://www.ranknfile-ue.org/uen_1877.html|doi= |accessdate=2008-05-25}}</ref> The next day, the militia mounted an assault on the strikers, shooting their way out of the roundhouse and killing 20 more people. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 21, 1877"|July 21–28, 1877 |East St. Louis, IL and St. Louis, MO | style="text-align: center;"|railroad, then general | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="18"|as many as 18 or more |[[1877 St. Louis general strike]] part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877: The first general strike in the United States was ended when 3000 federal troops and 5000 deputized police had killed at least 18 people in skirmishes around the city. |---- |July 23, 1877 |Reading, PA | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|10 |In the [[Reading Railroad massacre]], part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877, a unit of the [[Pennsylvania State Police]] ventured into the Seventh Street Cut (a man-made railway ravine) to address a train disabled by rioters. They were bombarded from above with bricks and stones, harassed, and finally they fired a rifle volley into the crowd at the far end, killing ten.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://explorepahistory.com/hmarker.php?markerId=1-A-1AD|title= Reading Railroad Massacre Historical Marker|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref><ref>Anthracite's Demise and the Post-Coal Economy of Northeastern Pennsylvania, by Thomas Keil, Jacqueline M. Keil, 2014, page 39</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 25, 1877"|July 25–26, 1877 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|30 |[[Battle of the Viaduct]], part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877: Violence erupted between a crowd and police, federal troops, and state militia at the Halsted Street Viaduct. When it ended, 30 were dead.<ref>{{cite book|first=Richard |last=Schneirov|title=Labor and Urban Politics: Class Conflict and the Origins of Modern Liberalism in Chicago, 1864-97|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Urbana and Chicago, Illinois, U.S.|year=1998|pages=75, 95|isbn=978-0252066764| quote=Police violence had taken a terrible toll: approximately thirty were killed − the true number could not be reported since many were buried at night in lime pits south of the city − and another two hundred were wounded. (These figures are estimates based on comparing newspaper accounts and names of casualties.) Not one policeman or militiaman was killed.}}</ref>
|---- |August 1, 1877 |Scranton, PA | style="text-align: center;"|coal, railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|4 |[[Scranton General Strike]], part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877: The day after railroad workers conceded and returned to work, angry striking miners clashed with a 38-man posse partly led by [[William Walker Scranton]], general manager of the Lackawanna Iron & Coal Company. When a posse member was shot in the knee, the posse responded by killing or fatally wounding four of the strikers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thomasgenweb.com/hyde_park_history.html|title=Hyde Park History|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref><ref name=scranton>{{cite book|title= New England Families, Genealogical and Memorial: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of Commonwealths and the Founding of a Nation, Volume 4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NfksAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1841&lpg=PA1841&dq=Worthington+Scranton+mining+1871&source=bl&ots=mJL1oImxum&sig=GoNlyYjhFZVYq3jQqW2b2cLJXXA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAGoVChMIt9jDtKjwxwIVkJmICh1FnQXJ#v=onepage&q=Worthington%20Scranton%20mining%201871&f=false|page=1841|editor-first=William|editor-last=Cutter|year=1913|accessdate=2015-09-11|publisher=Lewis Historical Publishing Company}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="August 2, 1877"|1877 |Philadelphia, PA | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="21"|20–30 |[[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]: 30–70 injured in addition to those killed<ref name=Ferguson>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9F08RUn2ot8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Emma Goldman: Political Thinking in the Streets| first=Kathy E.|last= Ferguson| publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|location =Lanham, Maryland, USA|date= April 16, 2011}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="August 4, 1877"|1877 |Buffalo, NY | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|8 |[[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]: 8 killed<ref name="Ferguson"/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |May 4, 1885 |Lemont, Illinois | style="text-align: center;"|quarry | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|2 |Troops of the Illinois state militia, pitted against "the most desperate and howling mob" of immigrant quarrymen and their women, throwing cobblestones, fired into the crowd. They killed two Polish strikers, Jacob Kugawa and Henry Stiller, and wounded several others with bayonets.<ref>{{cite news|title=The First Blood A Collision Between the Militia and the Strikers at Lemont|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/illinois/bloomington/bloomington-weekly-leader/1885/05-07/page-4?tag=strikers+killed|accessdate=20 April 2016|publisher=Bloomington Illinois Weekly Leader|date=7 May 1885}}</ref> |---- |April 28, 1886 |St. Louis, Missouri | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Striker John Gibbons, fatally shot by a "non-union switchman and private watchman" in St. Louis, was among ten known casualties of the [[Great Southwest railroad strike of 1886]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The official history of the great strike of 1886 on the Southwestern railway system|date=1886|publisher=Missouri Bureau of Labor Statistics|page=113|url=https://archive.org/details/officialhistoryo00miss|accessdate=7 April 2016}}</ref>{{Dubious| The source describes simple self-defense against 3 attackers.|date=April 2016}} |---- |data-sort-type="date"|May 3, 1886 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|machinery mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|4 |McCormick Harvester strike<ref name=Ferguson/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |May 5, 1886 |Milwaukee, WI | style="text-align: center;"|building trades | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|15 |[[Bay View Massacre]]: As protesters chanted for an 8-hour workday, 250 state militia were ordered to shoot into the crowd as it approached the iron rolling mill at Bay View, leaving 7 dead at the scene, including a 13-year-old boy. The Milwaukee Journal reported that eight more died within 24 hours. |---- |November 5, 1887 |Pattersonville, LA | style="text-align: center;"|sugar | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="20"|as many as 20 |10,000 sugar workers (90% of whom were black), organized by the [[Knights of Labor]], went on strike. A battalion of national guardsmen supporting a sheriff's posse massacred as many as 20 people in the black village of Pattersonville, [[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Uncivil war: five New Orleans street battles and the rise and fall of radical Reconstruction|first=James Keith|last=Hogue|page=191|publisher=LSU Press|year=2011}}</ref> |---- |November 23, 1887 |Thibodaux, LA | style="text-align: center;"|sugar | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="37"|37 or more estimated |[[Thibodaux Massacre]]: Louisiana Militia, aided by bands of prominent citizens, shot at least 35 unarmed black sugar workers striking to gain a dollar-per-day wage and lynched two strike leaders. "No credible official count of the victims was ever made; bodies continued to turn up in shallow graves outside of town for weeks to come."<ref>{{cite book|first=Rebecca Jarvis|last=Scott|title=Degrees of Freedom: Louisiana and Cuba after Slavery|publisher=Belknap Press|year=2008|page=85|isbn=978-0674027596}}</ref> |---- |April 3, 1891 |Morewood, PA | style="text-align: center;"|coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|9 |[[Morewood massacre]]: Miners struck the coke works of industrialist [[Henry Clay Frick]] for higher wages and an 8-hour work day.<ref name="morewood-oldminer">{{cite web|url=http://patheoldminer.rootsweb.ancestry.com/morewood2.html|title=Massacre at Morewood Mine & Coke Works, (Coal Miners Strike of 1891)|accessdate=2008-05-10|last1=Washlaski|first1=Raymond A.|first2=Ryan P.|last2=Washlaski|date=2006-11-12|work=Virtual Museum of Coal Mining in Western Pennsylvania}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://explorepahistory.com/hmarker.php?markerId=1-A-2CB|title=Morewood Massacre [Bituminous Coal] Historical Marker|accessdate=2015-09-12|work=ExplorePAhistory.com|publisher=WITF, Inc.|location=Harrisburg, Pennsylvania}}</ref> As a crowd of about 1000 strikers accompanied by a brass band marched on the company store, deputized members of the 10th Regiment of the National Guard fired several volleys <ref>{{cite book|title=Official Documents, Comprising the Department and Other Reports Made to the Governor, Senate and House of Representatives of Pennsylvania, Volume 4|date=1892|publisher=State of Pennsylvania|page=D - 8}}</ref> into the crowd, killing 6 strikers and fatally wounding 3.<ref name="morewood-oldminer"/> |---- |July 6, 1892 |Homestead, PA | style="text-align: center;"|steel | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|9 |[[Homestead Massacre]]: An attempt by 300 [[Pinkerton Agency|Pinkerton]] guards hired by the company to enter the [[Carnegie Steel]] plant via the river was repulsed by strikers. In the ensuing gun battle, 9 strikers and 7 Pinkerton guards were shot and killed. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 7, 1892"|July 1892 |Coeur d'Alene, ID | style="text-align: center;"|hardrock mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|4 |[[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor strike of 1892]]: In July a union miner was killed by mine guards.<ref>{{cite report|author1=Taft, Philip|author2=Ross, Philip|title=American Labor Violence: Its Causes, Character, and Outcome|work=The History of Violence in America: A Report to the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence|editor-first1=Hugh Davis| editor-last1=Graham|editor-first2=Ted Robert|editor-last2=Gurr|year=1969|publisher=Frederick A. Praeger}}</ref> Company guards also fired into a saloon where union men were sheltering, killing 3. |---- |May 23, 1894 |Uniontown, PA | style="text-align: center;"|coal | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5.1"|5+ |The [[Bituminous coal miners' strike of 1894]] was organized by the [[United Mine Workers]] in multiple mid-Western states on April 21, ending in late June. Among many other violent incidents in Illinois, Ohio, and elsewhere, five strikers were killed and eight wounded by guards near [[Uniontown, Pennsylvania]] on May 23.<ref>W. T. Stead, Incidents of Labor War in America, [http://books.google.com/books?id=jpHQAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA69 The Contemporary Review], Vol. LXVI, No. 1, July 1894; pages 65–74.</ref> |---- |July 7, 1894 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="13"|30 or more estimated |[[Pullman Strike]]: An attempt by [[Eugene V. Debs]] to unionize the Pullman railroad car company in suburban Chicago developed into a strike on May 10, 1894. Other unions were drawn in. On June 26 a national rail strike of 125,000 workers paralyzed traffic in 27 states for weeks. By July 3 a mob peaking at perhaps 10,000 had gathered near the shoreline in south Chicago embarking on several straight days of vandalism and violence, burning switchyards and hundreds of railroad cars. Thousands of federal troops and deputy marshals were inserted over the governor's protests and clashed with rioters. The strike dissolved by August 2. Debs biographer [[Ray Ginger]] calculated thirty people killed in Chicago alone.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ray Ginger|title=Eugene V. Debs |year=1962|publisher=Macmillan |page=170|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Historian David Ray Papke, building on the work of Almont Lindsey published in 1942, estimated another 40 killed in other states.<ref>{{cite book|author=David Ray Papke|title=The Pullman Case: The Clash of Labor and Capital in Industrial America. Landmark law cases & American society|year=1999|publisher=University Press of Kansas|pages=35–37|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Property damage exceeded $80 million.<ref>{{cite book|author=John R. Commons|title=History of Labour in the United States'' vol 2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6J1ShTnok40C&pg=PA502|year=1918|publisher=Macmillan |page=502|display-authors=etal}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1896"|1896–1897 |Leadville, CO | style="text-align: center;"|silver mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5.99"|as many as 11 |[[Leadville Miners' strike]]: The union asked for a wage increase of 50 cents-per-day for those making less than $3-per-day, to restore a 50-cent cut imposed in 1893. The county sheriff and his deputies supported the strikers. Leadville city police took the side of the mine owners, recruited new officers from Denver, and "apparently kept up a near-constant campaign of harassment and violence against union members throughout the strike." As many as six union men were killed during the strike, by strikebreakers, police, or under mysterious circumstances. In the summer of 1921 in [[Mingo County, West Virginia|Mingo County]], hundreds of miners were arrested without [[habeas corpus]] and other basic legal rights. Talk spread of a march to free those confined miners, end martial law, and organize the county. In [[Kanawha County, West Virginia|Kanawha County]], up to 13,000 miners gathered and began marching toward [[Logan County, West Virginia|Logan County]] on August 24. The reviled anti-union sheriff of Logan County, [[Don Chafin]]<ref>The Herald-Dispatch. [http://www.wvculture.org/History/government/chafindon01.html "Funeral Rites Thursday For Colorful Don Chafin"], August 10, 1954.</ref> set up defenses on Blair Mountain, with the nation's largest private armed force of 2000. By August 29, battle was fully joined. Chafin's men, though outnumbered, had the advantage of higher positions and better weaponry. Private hired planes dropped homemade bombs on the miners near the towns of Jeffery, Sharples and Blair. Army bombers were used for aerial surveillance. Sporadic gun battles continued for a week. Up to 30 deaths were reported by Chafin's side and 50–100 on the union miners' side, with hundreds more injured. On September 2, federal troops arrived by presidential order, and the miners started heading home the next day. ===Execution by the state=== :{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; font-size:87%; border:1; cellpadding:5; cellspacing:0;" !scope="col" data-sort-type="date"|Date !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Type of dispute !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Workers executed by the State !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Notes |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="June 21, 1877"|June 21, 1877 – October 9, 1879<ref>{{cite book|title=Labor's Story in the United States|first=Philip Yale|last=Nicholson|year=2004|publisher=Temple University Press|page=108|isbn=9781592132393|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7I2dxUSB9WUC&pg=PA108&lpg=PA108&dq=%22milton+shapp%22+pardon+kehoe&source=bl&ots=ZU-ezd2Hkt&sig=EMgumnbEIYCE8Q6_o5t42OzYBok&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAWoVChMIiK_f7fDyxwIVQyyICh1smAFs#v=onepage&q=%22milton%20shapp%22%20pardon%20kehoe&f=false}}</ref> |Pennsylvania (Pottsville, Mauch Chunk, Bloomsburg, Sunbury) | style="text-align: center;"|coal mining strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="20"|20 |A 20% pay cut in December, 1874, led to a long strike that began on January 1, 1875,<ref name=Boyer>{{cite book|title=Labor's Untold Story|last1=Boyer|first1=Richard O.|last2=Morais|first2=Herbert M.|publisher=United Workers|year=1974}}</ref><sup>p. 51</sup> and quickly turned violent. Several company bosses were killed. Bodies of militant miners were sometimes found in deserted mine shafts.<ref name=Boyer/><sup>p. 53</sup> 20 workers (suspected [[Molly Maguires]])<ref name=Kenny>{{cite book|last=Kenny|first=Kevin|title=Making Sense of the Molly Maguires|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0195116311|year=1998}}</ref><sup>pp. 5,10</sup> were tried for murder and convicted largely on testimony of a [[Pinkerton (detective agency)|Pinkerton]] spy.<ref name=Kenny/><sup>pp. 234–35</sup><ref name=Bloom/> Three of the defendants confessed: Manus Cull, Francis McHugh, and Patrick Butler, as did Molly Maguire member “Powder Keg” Kerrigan. Their confessions and testimony corroborated that of Pinkerton agent McParlan. Historians have written that the murder charge against John Keyhoe, the subject of a later trial, remains dubious.<ref>Prof. Douglas O. Linder, Famous trials: [http://law2.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/maguires/mollytrialaccount.html An account of the Molly Maguires], University of Missouri at Kansas City, 2010.</ref> [[Franklin B. Gowen]], owner of the Philadelphia & Reading Railroad and the person who hired Pinkerton, had himself appointed special prosecutor.<ref name=Boyer/><sup>p. 54</sup><ref>{{cite book|title=[[Political Repression in Modern America]]|author=Goldstein, Robert Justin|publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]]|year=2001|isbn=0-252-06964-1|page=29}}</ref> The 20 men were hanged by the State of Pennsylvania. {{Quote|"The Molly Maguire trials were a surrender of state sovereignty. A private corporation initiated the investigation through a private detective agency. A private police force arrested the alleged defenders, and private attorneys for the coal companies prosecuted them. The state provided only the courtroom and the gallows. ... Any objective study of the tenor of the times and the entire record must conclude that (the Mollies) ... did not have fair and impartial juries. They were, therefore, denied one of the fundamental rights that [[William Penn]] guaranteed to all of Pennsylvania’s citizens."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Hard Coal Docket: 150 Years of the Bench & Bar of Carbon County (1843-1993)|last=Lavelle|first=John P.|year=1994|publisher=Times News}}</ref>}} Following an investigation 100 years after his death, John Kehoe was posthumously pardoned by [[Milton Shapp|the governor]], who wrote, "[I]t is impossible for us to imagine the plight of the 19th Century miners in Pennsylvania's anthracite region. ... We can be proud of the men known as the Molly Maguires",<ref name=Bloom>{{cite web|url=http://www.historynet.com/molly-macguires-in-pennsylvania-coal-regions.htm|first=Joseph|last=Bloom|title=Molly {{sic|MacGuires|nolink=y}} in Pennsylvania Coal Regions|date=June 12, 2006|accessdate=2015-09-12}}</ref> whom he praised as "these martyred men of labor".<ref name=Kenny/><sup>p. 284</sup> |---- |November 11, 1887 |Illinois | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5"|4 hanged on Nov. 11, 1887 ([[Albert Parsons]], [[August Spies]], [[George Engel]], [[Adolph Fischer]]) 1 suicide on Nov. 10, 1887 ([[Louis Lingg]]) |On May 4, 1886, one day after police fired into a crowd of striking McCormick Harvesting Machine workers outside Chicago, 3000 people rallied at Chicago's [[Haymarket affair|Haymarket Square]] to protest the police brutality.<ref name=TESAH/> A bomb thrown at the rally caused police to open fire, killing at least one worker and injuring many. Blamed for the Haymarket bomb, four labor leaders were eventually hanged and one committed suicide the day before the scheduled executions. The prosecution admitted that none of eight defendants was involved in the bombing. In 1893 Illinois Governor [[John Peter Altgeld]] found that "much of the evidence given in the trial was pure fabrication," and that the police had bribed and "terrorized ignorant men" or threatened witnesses "with torture if they refused to swear to anything desired."<ref>{{cite book|title=Labor's Untold Story|last1=Boyer|first1=Richard O.|last2=Morais|first2=Herbert M.|publisher=Marzani and Munsell, Inc.|year=1955|page=98}}</ref> |---- |November 19, 1915 |Utah | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="1"|[[Joe Hill]] |Joe Hill, [[IWW]] labor organizer and songwriter, was executed by firing squad by the State of Utah for the murder of a grocer, despite worldwide protests and two attempts to intervene by President [[Woodrow Wilson]]. With the backing of the IWW, his conviction was appealed to the Utah Supreme Court. Citing dozens of alleged errors in procedure and fairness, attorney O.N. Hilton called Hill's case "utterly lacking in the essential fundamentals of proof."<ref>{{cite book|first=Gibbs M.|last=Smith|title=Joe Hill|publisher=Peregrine Smith Books|year=1984|location=Salt Lake City, Utah|page=105}}</ref> Recent research findings support "that the circumstantial case made against the man who ultimately was executed for the crime was nowhere near as convincing as the one that could and should have been made against (Frank Z.) Wilson," who was a serial criminal well-known to police, who picked him up mere blocks from the murder, detained him and then let him go.<ref>{{cite book|first=William|last=Adler|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|year=2012|page=61|isbn=978-1608194605|title=The Man Who Never Died: The Life, Times, and Legacy of Joe Hill, American Labor Icon}}</ref> |---- |}

The Committee for the Defense of Civil Rights in Tampa stated, "The Tampa cigar bosses carry on a constant campaign to prevent the organization of cigar makers unions."<ref name= cdcrt>{{cite report|title=Tampa – Tar and Terror|publisher=Committee for the Defense of Civil Rights in Tampa|location=New York City|year=1935|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735061543876.pdf}}</ref><sup>p. 8</sup> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 9, 1911"|January 9–13, 1911 |Somerset, KY | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|racial labor rules | style="text-align: center;"|9 |White firemen of the [[Cincinnati, New Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway]] (part of the [[Queen and Crescent Route]]) struck on January 9, 1911, when the company refused their demand that their black counterparts be fired within 90 days. Trains continued to run, with black firemen on their crews, in the vicinity of [[Kings Mountain, Kentucky]], [[Somerset, Kentucky]], and [[Oakdale, Tennessee]], in terrain well-suited for sniper attacks. At least eleven people were killed by sharpshooters within four days, nine of them black railroad employees, and two detectives.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eleven Men Killed in Firemen's Strike|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/new-york/new-york/new-york-times/1911/03-13?tag=detective+james+carl+glenmary+1911|accessdate=2 April 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=13 March 1911}} Subsequent reports of a total twenty dead are harder to substantiate: see {{cite news|title=Twenty Dead Now in Firemen's Strike|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/new-york/new-york/new-york-times/1911/03-16/page-3?tag=detective+james+carl+glenmary+1911|accessdate=2 April 2016|agency=New York Times|date=16 March 1911}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="October 3, 1911"|October 3, 1911 through January 25, 1912 | Illinois, California, Utah, Mississippi | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|5 | Five of the twelve known casualties of the [[Illinois Central shopmen's strike of 1911]] were strikers: Robert Mitchell, Cairo Illinois, October 3;<ref>{{cite news|title=Strike Breakers are in Conflict|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/texas/laredo/laredo-weekly-times/1911/10-08/page-5?tag=houston+strike+pipes+killed+1911|accessdate=1 April 2016|publisher=Laredo (TX) Weekly Times|date=10 October 1911}}</ref> Lem Haley, McComb Mississippi, October 4;<ref>{{cite news|title=Troops at M'Comb Stop Strike Riots|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/new-york/new-york/new-york-times/1911/10-05?tag=truly+curtis+carl+canton+mccomb+1911|accessdate=2 April 2016|agency=New York Times|date=5 October 1911}}</ref> J.S. Coldereau, Bakersfield California, November 25, 1911;<ref name="U.S. Government Printing Office">{{cite book|title=Industrial Relations: Final Report and Testimony, United States Commission on Industrial Relations|date=1916|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|page=9878|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4aMsAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> John G. Hayden, Salt Lake City, December 5;<ref>{{cite news|title=Union Man Shot|url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19111206.2.75.3|accessdate=7 April 2016|issue=Volume 111, Number 6|publisher=San Francisco Call|date=6 December 1911}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Railway Carmen's Journal|date=1913|page=491|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yd5JAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA491|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> and Ed Lefevre, Mojave California, January 25.<ref name="U.S. Government Printing Office"/> |---- |August 3, 1913 |Wheatland, CA | style="text-align: center;"|agriculture | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |[[Wheatland Hop Riot]]: Fighting broke out when sheriff's deputies attempted to arrest [[IWW]] leader Richie "Blackie" Ford as he addressed striking field workers at the Durst Ranch. Four people died, including two workers, the local district attorney and a deputy. Despite the lack of evidence against them, Ford and another strike leader were found guilty of murder.<ref name="archive20140731042216">{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |title=Today in Labor History |author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute |location=Rochester, New York |accessdate=2015-09-16 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140731042216/http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |archivedate=July 31, 2014 }}</ref> |- |December 7, 1913 |Painesdale, MI | style="text-align: center;"|copper mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|3 |Dally-Jane murders: Part of the [[Copper Country strike of 1913–1914|Copper Country Strike of 1913-1914]]. Three striking miners (two Finnish brothers named Huhta and an Austrian) fired random rifle shots from 50 yards into the boarding house of Thomas Dally on Baltic Street, which housed replacement miners. The gunshots killed Dally and two English brothers, William Arthur Jane and Thomas Henry Jane. The attached house also received fire, injuring 13-year-old Mary Nicholson.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Dally-Jane Murders in Painesdale during the Copper Strike of 1913-14 (A personal account) | url= http://www.copperrange.org/strike.htm | first=Kevin |last=Musser|accessdate=2015-01-01}}</ref> |---- |December 24, 1913 |Red Jacket, MI | style="text-align: center;"|copper mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="11"|11 (plus 62 children) |[[Italian Hall disaster]]: As the [[Copper Country strike of 1913–1914]] dragged on into the cold of December, the hatred on both sides grew.<ref name=filipelli/><sup>p. 326</sup> [[Anna Klobuchar Clemenc]] and the Women's Auxiliary of the [[Western Federation of Miners]] organized a Christmas-Eve party for strikers and their families. The hall was packed with 400 to 500 people when someone shouted "fire". There was no fire, but 73 people, 62 of them children, were crushed to death trying to escape. |---- |August 1, 1917 |Butte, MT | style="text-align: center;"|copper mining | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[Industrial Workers of the World|IWW]] organizer [[Frank Little (unionist)|Frank Little]] was lynched by six masked men. 10,000 workers lined the route of his funeral procession. Years later writer [[Dashiell Hammett]] would recall his early days as a Pinkerton detective agency operative and recount how a mine company representative offered him $5,000 to kill Little.<ref name="archive20140731042216"/> |---- |September 30, 1919 |Elaine, AR | style="text-align: center;"|agriculture | style="text-align: center;"|organizing, race | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="100"|up to 100 or more |African-American farmers met to establish the [[Progressive Farmers and Household Union of America]] to fight for better pay and higher cotton prices. They were shot at by a group of whites and returned the fire. News of the confrontation spread and the [[Elaine race riot]] ensued, leaving at least 100 blacks dead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |title=Today in Labor History |author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute |location=Rochester, New York |accessdate=2015-09-16 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001172317/http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |archivedate=October 1, 2013 }}</ref> |---- |November 11, 1919 |Centralia, WA | style="text-align: center;"|lumber | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[Centralia Massacre (Washington)|Centralia Massacre]]: Two American Legion members in an Armistice Day parade were shot dead by IWW members firing rifles, after which the unarmed Legionaires attempted to force their way into the IWW hall. Two more were shot dead by members of the IWW, after which an IWW organizer named [[Wesley Everest]] was lynched by vigilantes. |---- |November 22, 1919 |Bogalusa, LA | style="text-align: center;"|lumber | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|4 |Gunmen hired by the Great Southern Lumber Company converged on the organizing office of the International Union of Timber Workers and without warning began to shoot. Lem Williams was shot down at the front door, and J.P. Bouchillon and Thomas Gaines were then killed as each appeared at the doorway. Stanley O'Rourke attempted to leave by the back door where he was shot while coming out with his hands above his head.<ref>{{cite book|first1=Horace Mann|last1=Bond|first2=Julia W.|last2=Bond|title=The Star Creek Papers| editor-first=Adam|editor-last=Fairclough|publisher=University of Georgia Press|year=1997|page=13|isbn=978-0820319049}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bloody Bogalusa, 1919: When Four White Unionists Died Defending Their Black Comrades|url=http://www.internationalist.org/bloodybogalusa19191202.html|work=The Internationalist|date=February 2012|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> |---- |August 5, 1920 |Denver, CO | style="text-align: center;"|streetcar | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|7 |[[Denver streetcar strike of 1920]]: Seven workers were killed and 80 others wounded over two nights of violent riots triggered by a streetcar strike.<ref>{{cite book | last = Devine | first = Edward T. | title = The Denver tramway strike of 1920 : report of an investigation made under the auspices of the Denver Commission of Religious Forces | publisher = The Denver Commission of Religious Forces | location = New York | year = 1921 | url =http://books.google.com/books?id=iCBYAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1923"|Jan-Feb, 1923 |Oklahoma City, OK and Fort Worth TX | style="text-align: center;"|meatpacking | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Two black strikebreaking meat packers were lynched during the [[Amalgamated Meat Cutters]] strike of 1921-22: Jake Brooks in Oklahoma City on January 14, 1922,<ref>{{cite news|title=Sixth Man Pleads in Lynching Case|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/texas/san-antonio/san-antonio-express/1922/01-26/page-7?tag=jake+brooks+oklahoma+city+lynching|accessdate=27 March 2016|publisher=San Antonio Express|date=January 26, 1922}}</ref> and an unnamed injured black meatpacker, kidnapped by the [[Ku Klux Klan|Klan]] from a hospital and lynched in February.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rick Halpern|first1=Roger Horowitz|title=Meatpackers: An Oral History of Black Packinghouse Workers and Their Struggle for Racial and Economic Equality|date=1999|publisher=NYU Press|page=101}}</ref> |---- |January 16, 1923 |Harrison, AR | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |The “Harrison Railroad Riot”: striking railroad worker Ed C. Gregor was jailed for discharging a shotgun in the air to fend off a mob, then kidnapped from jail and lynched on a railroad bridge. Other fellow AFL members were taken from their homes and flogged. The Klan had allied with townspeople, under economic pressure from the strike, to combat the strikers and their campaign of railroad bridge arson.<ref>http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=3700</ref> |---- |September 14, 1929 |Gastonia, NC | style="text-align: center;"|textile | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Textile mill striker and songwriter Ella May Wiggins, 29, a mother of five, was killed when local vigilantes forced the pickup truck in which she was riding off the road and began shooting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95|title=Today in Labor History|author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute|location=Rochester, New York|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> |---- |March 6, 1930 |Philadelphia, PA | style="text-align: center;"|garment | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |One man, Carl Mackley, was shot to death and three others were wounded seriously in a battle between employees of the H. C. Aberle hosiery mills and members of the hosiery workers' union and their sympathizers.<ref>{{cite news|title=HOSIERY WORKER SLAIN When Mill Employees, Members of Union, Engage in Battle.| work= The Cincinnati Enquirer|location=Cincinnati, Ohio|date= March 7, 1930|page=15|accessdate=2016-08-11|url= https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/103453042/}}</ref> |---- |February 24, 1931 |Stroudsburg, PA | style="text-align: center;"|textile | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Twenty-year-old striking hosiery mill worker Alberta Bachman was shot and killed, and two others wounded, by a former striker who had returned to work. The former striker shot into a car he believed was going to throw rocks at his house. Bachman was a member of the American Federation of Full-Fashioned Hosiery Workers, striking Mammoth Mills.<ref>{{cite news|title=Girl Striker Killed, Two Wounded|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/wisconsin/madison/madison-wisconsin-state-journal/1931/02-24?|accessdate=25 March 2016|agency=Madison State Journal|date=24 February 1931|pages= 1, 4}}</ref> |---- |October 19, 1933 |Springfield, IL | style="text-align: center;"|coal | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |While on strike with [[Progressive Miners of America]] and in a protest march at the state capitol, Taylorville coal miner Melville Staples was shot once in the chest and died within 15 minutes.<ref>http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/illinois/alton/alton-evening-telegraph/1933/10-19?tag=kentucky+edgewater+coal+1934+killed</ref> The shooter was later identified as a local United Mine Workers official. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="December 22, 1933"|December 22, 1933 and March 15, 1934 |Hudson, MI | style="text-align: center;"|auto | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|2 |Two auto unionists were killed by the [[Black Legion (political movement)|Black Legion]]:<ref name=Ferguson/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} George Marchuk of the Auto Workers Union, and John Bielak of the Hudson Motor Local of the AFL, both Communist labor activitists found shot to death three months apart.<ref>{{cite book|title=Du Pont Dynasty: Behind the Nylon Curtain|publisher=Open Road Media|year=2014|first=Gerard|last=Colby|isbn=9780818403521|chapter=9}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="April 1, 1934"|April 1934 |Lakeland, FL | style="text-align: center;"|citrus | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Frank Norman, a citrus workers union organizer, was abducted by [[Ku Klux Klan|Klansmen]], and never seen or heard from again.<ref name= cdcrt/><sup>p. 9</sup> |---- |August 20, 1934 |Portland, Oregon | style="text-align: center;"|longshoremen | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |James Connor, a 22-year-old college student and newlywed working as a replacement worker on his vacation, was shot and killed in an altercation with striking longshoremen.<ref>Oregon Encyclopedia, “West coast waterfront strike of 1934,” written by Michael Monk, online at http://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/west_coast_waterfront_strike_of_1934/</ref> This was one of a string of violent incidents, including visiting Senator [[Robert F. Wagner]] coming under fire. A second replacement worker named R.A. Griffin was also wounded in the head. |---- |June 19, 1935 |Union, South Carolina | style="text-align: center;"|textiles | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |During a [[Textile Workers Union of America|United Textile Workers of America]] strike against Monarch Mills, a lunchtime fight at the mill gate became a riot. Overseer A.L. Stutts was shot and killed by Constable W.B. Franklin, who was then shot and killed by a third man.<ref>”Slain Constable Buried at Union”, Spartanburg Herald-Journal, June 22, 1935, page 1</ref> |---- |November 30, 1935 |Tampa, FL | style="text-align: center;"|cigar mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |In the 1930s, the [[Ku Klux Klan]] harassed and intimidated union leaders. On November 30, 1935, Tampa police raided an organizational meeting of "Modern Democrats" in a private home without a warrant. Joseph A. Shoemaker and five other organizers were taken to a Tampa police station.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e9ngAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA389&lpg=PA389&dq=%22Modern+Democrats%22+1935&source=bl&ots=M7ERjZ4Jtm&sig=3YbsPNxKqWMJpYMBf_1zfpM4iqw&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=%22Modern%20Democrats%22%201935&f=false|accessdate=2015-09-07|first=Robert P.|last=Ingalls|pages=13–27|via=Institutional Life: Family, Schools, Race, and Religion — American Cities – A Collection of Essays (Routledge), ed. Shumsky, Neil L. (2014)|title=The Tampa Flogging Case, Urban Vigilantism|work=Florida Historical Quarterly| isbn=9781135604738}}</ref> Five policemen then turned three of them over to a mob of Klansmen. Shoemaker died nine days later after he was stripped, flogged with tire chains, clubbed on the head, burned with a hot poker in the genitals, covered in boiling tar and feathers and paralyzed on one side. The cigar industry moguls of Tampa had actively opposed Shoemaker, had close ties to the police and posted bail for the arrested policemen.<ref name=cdcrt/> "A thorough investigation revealed that the murder resulted from a collaboration between Tampa Chief of Police R. G. Tittsworth and (the) local Klan."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Fiery Cross: The Ku Klux Klan in America|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1998|first=Wyn Craig|last=Wade|isbn=9780195123579|page=261}}</ref> |---- |November 3, 1979 |Greensboro, NC | style="text-align: center;"|textile | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5"|5 |Five labor organizers were killed at the [[Greensboro Massacre]], as workers were attempting to organize across racial lines at various textile mills in the area. A rally to protest recruitment at the mills by the Ku Klux Klan and Nazis turned violent, resulting in the deaths of the organizers. |---- |} :''*'' includes labor organizers

See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to the '''[[history of the United States]]'''.
{{TOC limit|limit=3}}
== By period == * [[Prehistory of the United States]] * [[History of the United States]] ** [[Pre-Columbian era]] ** [[Colonial history of the United States]] ** [[History of the United States (1776–1789)|1776–1789]] ** [[History of the United States (1789–1849)|1789–1849]] ** [[History of the United States (1849–1865)|1849–1865]] ** [[History of the United States (1865–1918)|1865–1918]] ** [[History of the United States (1918–1945)|1918–1945]] ** [[History of the United States (1945–1964)|1945–1964]] ** [[History of the United States (1964–1980)|1964–1980]] ** [[History of the United States (1980–1991)|1980–1991]] ** [[History of the United States (1991–present)|1991–present]]
=== Named eras and periods === These multi-year periods are commonly identified in American history. The existence and dating of some of these periods is debated by historians.
{{div col}} * [[Plantation era]] (c. 1700–c. 1860) * [[First Great Awakening]] (1730s–1740s) * [[American Revolution]] (1775–1783) * [[Second Great Awakening]] (c. 1800–c. 1840) * [[First-wave feminism]] (19th century–early 20th century) * [[Manifest Destiny]] (c. 1812–c. 1860) * [[Era of Good Feelings]] (c. 1817–c. 1825) * [[the Slave Power]] (c. 1840–c. 1875) * [[California Gold Rush]] (1848–1855) * [[American Civil War]] (1861-1865) * [[Reconstruction era (United States)|Reconstruction era]] (c. 1865–1877) * [[Gilded Age]] (1869–c. 1896) * [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow era]] (1876–1965) * [[Gay Nineties]] (1890s) * [[Nadir of American race relations]] (c. 1890–1940) * [[Progressive Era]] (1890s–1920s) * [[Lochner era]] (c. 1897–c. 1937) * [[American Century]] (20th century) * [[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]] (c. 1910–c. 1940) * [[First Red Scare]] (1917–1920) * [[Prohibition in the United States]] (1919–1933) * [[Roaring Twenties]] (1920s) * [[Jazz Age]] (1920s) * [[Great Depression in the United States|Great Depression]] (1929–1939) * [[Dust Bowl]] (1930–1936) * [[New Deal]] era (1933–1938) * [[Second Great Migration (African American)|Second Great Migration]] (c. 1941–c. 1970) * [[Cold War]] (1947–1991) * [[Second Red Scare]] (1947–1957) * [[Space Race]] (1957–1975) * [[Second-wave feminism]] (1960s–1970s) * [[New Great Migration]] (1965–present) * [[Détente]] (c. 1969–1979) * [[1970s energy crisis]] (1973–1980) * [[Reagan Era]] (1980–2008?) * [[Neoconservatism]] (1980s and 90s) * [[Dot-com bubble]] (c. 1995–2000) * [[United States housing bubble]] (c. 2001–c. 2005) * [[War on Terror]] (2001–present) {{div col end}}
;Political parties * [[First Party System]] (c. 1792–c. 1824) * [[Second Party System]] (c. 1828–c. 1854) * [[Third Party System]] (c. 1854–c. 1896) * [[Fourth Party System]] (c. 1896–c. 1932) * [[Fifth Party System]] (c. 1933–present)
;Wars See [[List of wars involving the United States]].
=== Timelines and lists === * [[Timeline of United States history]] * [[Years in the United States]]
==== 15th century ====
===== 1490s ===== * On October 12, 1492, three Spanish ships under the command of ''Cristoforo Colombo'' ([[Christopher Columbus]]) landed on the [[Lucayan people|Lucayan]] island of ''[[Guanahani]]'' which he names ''San Salvador'' (The Savior). * On November 14, 1493, a [[Spanish Navy|Spanish fleet]] under the command of Columbus lands on a large inhabited island which he names ''[[Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands|Santa Cruz]]'' (Holy Cross, now Saint Croix). Columbus then visits and names ''[[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|San Tomas]]'' (Saint Thomas) and ''[[Saint John, U.S. Virgin Islands|San Juan]]'' (Saint John). Columbus names the archipelago ''[[Saint Ursula|Santa Ursula y las Once Mil Vírgenes]]'' (Saint Ursula and her 11,000 virgins, now the [[Virgin Islands]]). * On November 19, 1493, Columbus lands on the large [[Taíno]] island of [[Borikén]] which he names ''[[Puerto Rico|San Juan Bautista]]'' ([[John the Baptist|Saint John the Baptist]], now [[Puerto Rico]]).
====16th century==== ===== 1500s ===== * On August 8, 1508, Spanish [[conquistador]] [[Juan Ponce de León]] establishes [[Capárra]], the first European settlement on the island of ''[[Puerto Rico|San Juan Bautista]]''.
===== 1510s ===== * On [[Easter Sunday]], April 2, 1513, a Spanish expedition led by [[Juan Ponce de León]] lands on a huge inhabited island (later determined to be a continental peninsula) which he names ''[[Spanish Florida|La Pascua Florida]]'' (the Feast of Flowers, now [[History of Florida|Florida]]).
===== 1520s ===== * On March 6, 1521, three Spanish ships under the command of ''Fernão de Magalhães'' ([[Ferdinand Magellan]]) land on the [[Island of Guam]] after a seemingly endless eleven week voyage across the Pacific Ocean. Magellan names the archipelago ''[[Mariana Islands|Las Isles de las Velas Latinas]]'' (The Islands of the Latine Sails). When the Spaniards refuse to pay for supplies, natives take iron from the ships. Magellan renames the archipelago ''[[Mariana Islands|Las Islas de los Ladrones]]'' (The Islands of the Thieves).
===== 1540s ===== * A Spanish expedition led by [[Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo]] lands at a bay of the Pacific Ocean which he names ''[[San Diego, California|San Miguel]]'' ([[Saint Michael]], now [[San Diego, California]]) on September 28, 1542.
===== 1550s ===== * A Spanish expedition led by [[Tristán de Luna y Arellano]] establishes a colony at ''[[Pensacola, Florida#History|Santa Maria de Ochuse]]'' ([[Pensacola, Florida#History|Pensacola, Florida]]) on August 15, 1559. ** A hurricane destroys most of the Ochuse colony five weeks later on September 19, 1559.
===== 1560s ===== * [[Jean Ribault]] explores the [[Jacksonville, Florida#History|Atlantic coast]] of [[Florida]] for France in 1562. * [[Huguenot|French Huguenots]] led by [[René Goulaine de Laudonnière]] establish [[Fort de la Caroline]] on June 22, 1564 * [[Spain|Spanish Governor]] [[Pedro Menéndez de Avilés]] establishes a colony about 10 [[league (unit)|leagues]] (56 kilometers or 35 miles) farther south at ''San Agustín'' ([[Saint Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]]) on September 8, 1565 * [[Spain|Spanish Governor]] [[Pedro Menéndez de Avilés]] captures ''Fort de la Caroline'' on September 20, 1565 ** Governor Menéndez orders the execution of 140 Huguenots from ''Fort de la Caroline'' and orders fort rebuilt as ''[[Fort Caroline|Fuerte San Mateo]]'' on September 29, 1565 ** Governor Menéndez orders the execution of Jean Ribault and 350 shipwrecked Huguenots on October 12, 1565 * French raiders led by [[Dominique de Gourgues]] destroy ''Fuerte San Mateo'' and murder all its defenders on April 27–28, 1567
===== 1570s ===== * Spanish [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit priests]] establish ''[[Ajacán Mission|Mission Santa Maria]]'' on ''[[Virginia Peninsula|Ajacán]]'' (the [[Virginia Peninsula]]) on September 10, 1570 – 1572
===== 1580s ===== * Spain, [[Portugal]], [[Italy]], and the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] adopt the new [[Gregorian calendar]] on October 15, 1582 ([[New Style]]) * English establish [[Roanoke Colony]] on [[Roanoke Island]] in [[Virginia Colony|Virginia]] (now [[North Carolina]]) in July 1585
===== 1590s ===== * A resupply party finds the Roanoke Colony dismantled and deserted on August 18, 1590 * [[Spanish governors of New Mexico|Spanish Governor]] [[Juan de Oñate Salazar]] founds the colony of ''[[Santa Fé de Nuevo Méjico]]'' ([[New Mexico]]) at ''[[San Juan de los Caballeros]]'' on July 11, 1598
