{{Infobox organization | name = Army and Navy Union of the United States of America | image = File:Army & Navy Union badge.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Army & Navy Union badge | motto = | predecessor = Regular Army Union of the United States of America | formation = {{start date and age|1888|03|31}} | status = Corporation | purpose = To alleviate suffering among soldiers and sailors | headquarters = | location = [[Niles, Ohio]] | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = worldwide | services = | membership = United States Armed Forces veterans and active duty | membership_year = | language = English | subsidiaries = [[garrisons]] | slogan = | mission = fraternal comradeship | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }}
The ''' Army and Navy Union of the United States of America ''' is the oldest veterans' organization in [[United States|America]]. It is open to all who had served honorably in the [[United States Armed Forces]] or who are now serving in one of the branches. The mission and purpose of the organization is to alleviate suffering of veterans by providing needed services. It is also to help active military service people in need through fraternal comradeship.
== History == [[File:Pacific Coast SF monument crop.jpg|thumb|Pacific Coast SF monument crop|thumb||Army and Navy Union monument]] [[File:Regular Army & Navy Union statue, SF National Cemetry inscription.JPG|thumb||The monument inscription at base]] The basis of the organization came in 1841. The organization transmuted further from other later war fighting groups like "The General Society of the War of 1812," " The Grand Army of the Republic," and "The Order of Indian Wars." These all had the same general philosophy, so had a common ground.<ref name=TWS>{{cite web |url=http://navy.togetherweserved.com/usn/servlet/tws.webapp.WebApp?cmd=AssocByShortName&name=76 |title=The Army and Navy Union USA |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2003-2011 |website= Military National |publisher=Together We Served |access-date=October 10, 2016 |quote=}}</ref> By 1886, it was realized that these exclusive organizations would naturally become extinct due to deaths if something wasn’t done to give them new life. The idea came about to restructure all these individual organizations into one permanent ongoing one. They founded the Army and Navy Union of the United States of America that was open to all who had served honorably in the United States Armed Forces.<ref name=TWS/>
A bill was introduced on July 17, 1985 in ninty-ninth Congress (1985–1986) to recognize the Army and Navy Union of the United States of America. It was signed by the President to become law on November 6, 1986.<ref name=A&N_law>{{cite web|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/99/s1456|title=S. 1456 (99th)|accessdate=October 12, 2016|author=99th Congress (1985)|date=July 17, 1985|work=Legislation |publisher=GovTrack.usaccess-date=October 12, 2016|quote=}}</ref> This patriotic organization was originally formed in [[Ohio]] by 30 men as "The Regular Soldiers' Union" on March 31, 1888.<ref name=FirstFormed>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Patriotic Organization |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7006203// |newspaper=Denton Journal |location=Denton, Maryland |date=January 31, 1925 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}</ref> The organization's name was amended to "Regular Army and Navy Union of the United States of America" on November 11, 1891{{sfn|USGovernment|1906|pages=173}} It was then reincorporated under the laws of Ohio on October 15, 1897.<ref name=ReIncorp> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=New Garrison To Embract Many |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7030207// |newspaper=Wilkes-Barre News |location=Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvannia |date=January 9, 1906 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}}} </ref> It was made official throughout the United States on October 19, 1899.{{sfn|USGovernment|1906|pages=174}} The federally chartered corporation is an organization under [[Title 36 of the United States Code|U.S. Code Title 36]], Subtitle II (Patriotic and National Organizations) of Part B (Organizations) as chapter 229.{{sfn|United States Government|2015|p=8}}{{sfn|US Government Printing Office|2003|p=537}}<ref name=36USC> {{cite web |url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/USCODE-1994-title36/html/USCODE-1994-title36-chap71.htm |title=United States Code, 1994 Edition, Title 36 - PATRIOTIC SOCIETIES AND OBSERVANCES; CHAPTER 71 - ARMY AND NAVY UNION OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2016 |website=U. S. Code |publisher=United States Government |access-date=October 14, 2016 |quote= The Army and Navy Union of the United States of America, organized and incorporated under the laws of the State of Ohio, is hereby recognized as such and is granted a charter. (Pub. L. 99–604, §1, Nov. 6, 1986, 100 Stat. 3446.)}} </ref><ref name=GovTrack> {{cite web |url= https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/99/hr897/text/enr |title=H.R. 897 (99th): A bill to recognize the Army and Navy Union of the United States of America. |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2016 |website=GovTrack |publisher=Civic Impulse LLC |access-date=October 14, 2016 |quote=}} </ref>
== Notable incidents and contributions ==
In February 1897 it was announced in the San Francisco Call newspaper that a stone monument to the memory of dead soldiers and sailors was to be raised at the [[San Francisco National Cemetery|United States national cemetery]], located in the [[Presidio of San Francisco|Presidio]] of [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], [[California]]. It was placed northeast of the Officer's Circle and finished on May 30. The veteran monument was dedicated on the next day on [[Memorial Day]] to the memory of past soldiers, sailors, and marines of the United States by the Army and Navy Union. There is an inscription on the front that says it was put up by the Pacific Coast garrisons.<ref name=PresidioMonument>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=New Monument to Dead Heroes |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6994136/presidio_army_navy_union_monument_1897/ |newspaper=San Francisco Call |location=San Francisco, California |date= February 7, 1897|via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}}}</ref>
The 17 foot 2 inch monument has on top of the base an 8 foot 4 inch statue of a figure of a soldier defending the flag. On the base is displayed the coat of arms of the United States and a stack of arms. There is also an image of light artillery on the front bottom. On the right cap is a flaming shell, on the die the American flag and jack, drums, and cannon-balls. The initiative to provide the monument was by California garrison #11.<ref name=PresidioMonument/>
The Wisconsin department of the Army and Navy Union announced it was on record as of August 1930 as favoring the state option of repealing the [[Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. The department was planning to pass on their commitment to the national convention at [[Buffalo, New York]], in October that they favored individual state laws instead on liquor control.<ref name=Prohibition>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Favors State Option in Matter of Prohibition |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7006931// |newspaper=Manitowoc Herald-Times |location=Manitowoc, Wisconsin |date=August 15, 1930 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}</ref>
The Army and Navy Union awarded publisher [[William Randolph Hearst]] the gold medal of honor for distinguished service in June 1945.<ref name=Hearst> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Of This ... And That |url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7031113// |newspaper=The Decatur Herald |location=Decatur, Illinois |date=June 19, 1945 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref> The [[Kings County]] division of the Union was awarded in a ceremony a plaque for outstanding service to convalescent sailors by the [[Brooklyn Naval Hospital]] on May 24, 1946.<ref name=BrookHosp> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Vet Group Honored For Service to Hospitalized Tars |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7030977// |newspaper=The Brooklyn Daily Eagle |location=Brooklyn, New York|date=May 25, 1946 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref> The Brooklyn Navy Yard garrison sponsored a reception at their headquarters on May 25, 1946, for Lieutenant [[Charles W. Shea]], recipient of the United States military [[Medal of Honor]], and Col. [[Richard E. Cole]] who had just returned from overseas duty.<ref name=returning> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Brooklyn Navy Yard Garrison |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7030768// |newspaper= The Brooklyn Daily Eagle |location=Brooklyn, New York |date=May 23, 1946 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref> The Union through their [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], division adopted a resolution on August 13, 1948, asking the government to provide a bonus for [[World War II]] veterans.<ref name=AskBonus> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Ask Bonus |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7030646// |newspaper=The Evening Independent |location= Massillon, Ohio |date=August 14, 1948 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref>
A district supreme court chief justice decided at the end of 1906 that a higher organization body cannot confiscate the property of one of the Union's garrisons. The decision then did not restrict admitting someone and/or their funds they were entitled to, to be admitted into a particular garrison.<ref name=NoHigherOrg>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Barry Garrison Upheld |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7003299// |newspaper=The Washington Post |location= Washington D.C.|date=December 23, 1906 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}</ref>
The Army and Navy Union of the United States of America provided medals of honor to certain union soldiers in 1905 who volunteered for duties above and beyond the call of duty. Their service, of which they did not receive pay for, was done in Maryland and Pennsylvania in 1863 during the [[American Civil War]].<ref name=AboveDuty>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Senate and House |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6994825// |newspaper=The Culver Citizen |location=Culver, Indiana |date= March 2, 1905 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}}}</ref><ref name=RightThing>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Right Thing or Nothing |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6995168// |newspaper=The Semi-weekly Times-Democrat |location=New Orleans, Louisiana |date=February 28, 1905 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}</ref>
== Activities in the past == [[Image:NA-Photograph of Freedom Train (19087862811).jpg|thumb|left|upright 0.65|Freedom Train of 1947]] The [[Kings County]] council in [[New York City]] of the Army and Navy Union under the command of General Samuel Hoch made available on September 27, 1947, an escort party for the families who were having their soldier dead brought home from World War II.<ref name=Flatbush> {{cite news |author=David Doyle |title= Army Navy Union |url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7044073//|newspaper= The Brooklyn Daily Eagle |location= Brooklyn, New York |date=September 21, 1947 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref> The organization participants gathered at the Flatbush Post of the American Legion on Nostrand Ave at 9 that morning to get their instructions from Hoch. He also coordinated the Brooklyn Naval Yard Garrison of the organization later that day that participated in the [[Freedom Train – 1947–49 station stops|Freedom Train Brooklyn display]] at the Vanderveer Park freight yards of the [[Long Island Rail Road]].<ref name=Part> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Army-Navy Union |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7034816// |newspaper=The Brooklyn Daily Eagle |location= Brooklyn, New York |date=September 27, 1947 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref> There were thousands that saw the one-day Brooklyn event that displayed [[Americana]] and original nineteenth-century historical documents in the rail cars.<ref name=SeeTrain> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=See Freedom Train |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7034835// |newspaper= The Brooklyn Daily Eagle |location= Brooklyn, New York |date=September 28, 1947 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref> Many were not able to get to see the displays that day and planned on viewing the next day when the train would stop a few miles away at [[Jamaica, Queens|Jamaica, Queens, New York]].<ref name=SeeTrain/> {{clear}} The Army and Navy Union began its seventeenth biennial convention in [[Washington, D.C.]] on September 20, 1915. The encampment was coordinated by General Oden Lake, their national commander. There were about 25,000 visitors during this convention, including members of the Army and Navy Union. There was a suite of rooms reserved at the [[New Willard Hotel]] for encampment headquarters from June 1 until September 30, 1915. A large parade was part of September convention, which involved all the veteran organizations of the Washington area garrisons. The program of events included a grand military ball and a banquet with high ranking government officials.<ref name=17thBiennial> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= 25,000 Expected to Visit Capital / Army and Navy Encampment will be held here in September|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1915-03-06/ed-1/seq-5/ |newspaper= The Evening Star |location=Washington, D.C. |date= |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref>
The Army and Navy Union began its eighteenth biennial convention at the Bohemian Hall in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], on September 12, 1917. The welcome address was given by Maryland governor [[Emerson Harrington]] to 500 delegates. General Oden Lake also spoke at this convention and announced that he would not be running again as their national commander. The next day was scheduled a banquet reception and later in the week an old-time campfire event. Overall there were about 2000 visitors to this convention.<ref name=18Biennial> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=To Greet Army Navy Union |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7030483// |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |location=Baltimore, Maryland |date=September 12, 1917 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}}}} </ref>
President [[Theodore Roosevelt|President Theodore Roosevelt]] delivered a memorial address to thousands at [[Portsmouth, Virginia]], on May 30, 1906, under the auspices the Army and Navy Union that concluded with the unveiling of a monument erected at [[Cedar Grove Cemetery (Portsmouth, Virginia)|the local Naval Cemetery]].<ref name=Portsmouth> {{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=President in Memoriam |url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7033960// |newspaper=The Charlotta Observer |location=Charlotta, North Carolina |date= May 31, 1906 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }} </ref> The Union began its thirteenth biennial convention in the [[Grand Army of the Republic|GAR Hall]] on Pennsylvania Avenue in [[Washington D.C.]] on July 17, 1907. It was also the ninth anniversary of the [[Battle of Santiago de Cuba]]. They sent a telegram of fraternal greetings to President Roosevelt that morning. A few hours later they received a telegram back from the President's secretary of thanks and best wishes for success of the Union.<ref name=RooseTele>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Veterans in Reunion |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7003856// |newspaper=The Washington Post |location=Washington D.C. |date=July 18, 1907 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}</ref>
Garrisons of the Army and Navy Union of the United States of America were in most states by 1906. They were also in Guantanamo, Cuba, Philippine Islands, and China. The Alfred Darte Garrison #41 mustered in a large class on October 20, 1906. This garrison had meetings the first and third Saturday's of each month at the Grand Army Hall of the Wilkes-Barre Army and Navy Union. The were planning on another group of several new members to join their garrison on an initiation for November 17, 1906.<ref name=garrison41>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Large Class will be initiated in the Next meeting |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6995768/wilkesbarre_times_leader_the_evening/ |newspaper= Wilkes-Barre Times Leader, the Evening News |location=Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvannia |date=October 23, 1906 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{open access}} }}</ref>
== Badge and metals ==
The original badge of the Army and Navy Union was patented as design No. 21640 on June 21, 1892.{{sfn|US Congressional Edition|1906|p=173}} The distinctive badge has been used since then and worn on public occasions of ceremony who are its members.{{sfn|USGovernment|1906|pages=173–174}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usmilitariaforum.com/forums/index.php?/topic/13328-army-navy-union-membership-badge/ |title=Army & Navy Union Membership badge |first1=Kevin |last1=Beyer December 16, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2015}}</ref> The United States Congress in 1913 authorized condemned [[American Civil War]] cannons to be melted down to provide medals to the members of the organization.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qNtGAQAAIAAJ&pg=PR98-IA19&lpg=PR98-IA19&dq=Army+and+Navy+Union+of+the+United+States+of+America&source=bl&ots=kpWUn1FNod&sig=jBNr0k6SECcM-mKuT5bpdNl_l7E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA_umM99nJAhUJGR4KHSrMB7QQ6AEITDAJ#v=onepage&q=Army%20and%20Navy%20Union%20of%20the%20United%20States%20of%20America&f=false |date=January 17, 1913 |title=Congressional Series of United States Public Documents, Volume 6330 |accessdate=December 12, 2015}}</ref>
== Qualifications and duties ==
There are no prescribed qualifications on time or length of service. The principal duty of the Army and Navy Union members is the upholding, guarding and protecting the integrity of the United States government and its constitution.{{sfn|United States Government|2015|p=145}} Other duties include helping ex-service personnel who need help in getting employment, caring for the sick, and needed burial services.<ref name=medaille>{{cite web |url=http://www.medal-medaille.com/army-navy-union-united-states-membership-badge-officer-p-6413.html |title= Army and Navy Union of the United States Membership Badge, officer|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2015 |website= |publisher=Medal-Medaille |access-date=December 14, 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
The mission and purpose of the Army and Navy Union are to bind together in fraternal comradeship all comrades, shipmates, soldiers, sailors and marines, regular and volunteers, veterans of all wars in which the United States has been or may be engaged in.{{sfn|State of Wisconsin|1927|p=431}} Besides patriotic other purposes for the organization are for history and genealogy records.{{sfn|State of Wisconsin|1927|p=438}} The main goal of the organization is to fraternally join all these veterans in a common semi-military group with similar backgrounds.{{sfn|State of Wisconsin|1927|p=432}}
== Present organization == The Army and Navy Union of the United States of America continues to operate garrisons in most states. Its National Headquarters is in [[Niles, Ohio]]. Any person who received an honorable discharge from or is now serving in the armed forces (active or reserve components) of the United States of America is eligible to become a member.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sites.google.com/site/armynavyunionusa/join-us |publisher=Army & Navy Union |title=Join us |work=USA&N Home page |access-date=December 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?path=/prelim@title36/subtitle2/partB/chapter229&edition=prelim |title=36 USC Ch. 229: ARMY AND NAVY UNION OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA From Title 36 – Patriotic and National Observances, Ceremonies and Organizations, Subtitle II – Patriotic and National Organizations Part B – Organizations |accessdate=December 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ies3AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA174&lpg=PA174&dq=Army+and+Navy+Union+of+the+United+States+of+America&source=bl&ots=J8QNHa0xU_&sig=_e761V24uqAbDVzg2X8b0bwGu9Q&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA_umM99nJAhUJGR4KHSrMB7QQ6AEISjAI#v=onepage&q=Army%20and%20Navy%20Union%20of%20the%20United%20States%20of%20America&f=false |work=United States Congressional serial set |issue=4908 |date=June 19, 1906 |title=The Army and Navy Union of the United States |accessdate=December 12, 2015}}</ref>
The Army and Navy Union's fundamental objective is national security and defense. Its overall purpose is to encourage and preserve fraternal comradeship among those who have rendered service in the United States Armed Forces. The organization has the ideal to continue high principles of patriotism, loyalty, justice, and service to the United States. It is the oldest veterans' organization in America.<ref name=AandN>{{cite web |url=https://sites.google.com/site/armynavyunionusa/ |title=Army & Navy Union USA |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date=December 14, 2015|quote=The Army & Navy Union USA was organized in 1886 and is the oldest, perpetual membership veterans organization in the United States. }}</ref><ref name=No65>{{cite web |url=http://armynavyunion.org/5401.html |title= Army and Navy Union – Defenses of Washington Garrison No.65|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2015 |website= |publisher=Army and Navy Union |access-date=December 14, 2015 |quote=Organized in 1886, it is the oldest, perpetual membership veterans organization in the United States. }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://huron.oh.networkofcare.org/mh/services/agency.aspx?pid=ArmyandNavyUnionoftheUnitedStatesofAmericaDepartmentofOhio_621_2_0&ageGrp= |publisher=Huron County Health and Addiction Services |work=Mental / Behavioral Health Service Directory |title=Army And Navy Union Of The United States Of America: Department Of Ohio (Information Provided By: Mental Health And Recovery Services Board Of Allen, Auglaize And Hardin Counties) |date=June 4, 2015 |accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Army and Navy union of the United States |work=[[New International Encyclopedia|The New International Encyclopædia]] |volume=4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S6NGAQAAIAAJ |first1=Daniel |last1=Coit |last2=Gilman |first2=Harry |first3=Thurston |last3=Peck |first4=Frank |last4=Moore |year=1907 |publisher=[[Dodd, Mead and Company|Mead and Company]] |accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |publisher=House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs |work=Veterans Service Organizations |title=Congressionally-Chartered Veterans Service Organizations (By Date of Charter) |url=https://veterans.house.gov/citizens/resources|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>

{{History of the United States}} The '''prehistory of the United States''' comprises the occurrences within regions now part of the [[United States of America]] during the interval of time spanning from the [[formation of the Earth]] to the documentation of local [[history]] in [[written form]]. At the start of the [[Paleozoic era]], what is now [[North America|"North" America]] was actually in the [[Southern hemisphere|southern]] [[Hemisphere of the Earth|hemisphere]]. Marine life flourished in the country's many seas, although terrestrial life had not yet evolved. During the latter part of the Paleozoic, seas were largely replaced by [[swamps]] home to [[amphibians]] and early [[reptiles]]. When the continents had assembled into [[Pangaea]] drier conditions prevailed. The [[Synapsids|evolutionary precursors]] to [[mammals]] dominated the country until a mass extinction event ended their reign.
The [[Triassic]], first period of the [[Mesozoic era]] followed. [[Dinosaurs]] evolved and began their rise to dominance, quickly spreading into the United States. Soon Pangaea began to split up and North America began drifting north and westward. During the [[Late Jurassic|latter]] [[Jurassic]], the floodplains of the western states were home to dinosaurs like ''[[Allosaurus]]'', ''[[Apatosaurus]]'', and ''[[Stegosaurus]]''. During the [[Cretaceous]], the [[Gulf of Mexico]] expanded until it split North America in half. [[Plesiosaurs]] and [[mosasaurs]] swam in its waters. Later into the period it began to withdraw and the coastal plains of the western states were home to dinosaurs like ''[[Edmontosaurus]]'', ''[[Triceratops]]'', and ''[[Tyrannosaurus]]''. Another mass extinction ended the reign of the dinosaurs.
The [[Cenozoic era]] began afterward. The inland sea of the Cretaceous gradually vanished and mammals were beginning to dominate the land. During the [[Eocene]] the western states were home to small primitive [[camels]] and [[horses]] as well as the carnivorous [[creodonts]]. Soon mammals had entered the oceans and the early [[whale]] ''[[Basilosaurus]]'' swam the coastal waters of the southeast. [[Rhino]]-like [[titanotheres]] dominated [[Oligocene]] South Dakota. From this point on the climate in the United States cooled until the [[Pleistocene]], when [[glacier]]s spread. [[Saber-toothed cat]]s, [[woolly mammoth]]s, [[mastodon]]s, and [[dire wolves]] roamed the land. [[Settlement of the Americas|Humans arrived across a land bridge]] between Siberia and Alaska and may have played a role in hunting these animals into extinction.
==Precambrian== [[File:Cianobacteris estructura.png|thumb|right|100px|"[[Blue-green alga]]".]] The oldest known [[eukaryotes]] lived around 1.4 billion years ago during the [[Precambrian]] near [[Beck Spring, California]]. These were [[photosynthetic]] organisms and produced [[oxygen]] as a byproduct of their [[physiology]]. The Beck Spring eukaryotes and other Precambrian photosynthesizers released the oxygen that now makes the planet's atmosphere breathable.<ref name="audubon-eucaryotes-40" /> Precambrian [[Blue-green algae]] remains from this age were preserved between [[Copper Harbor]] and [[Eagle harbor]] on the shoreline of [[Lake Superior]] in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.<ref name="50states-michigan-157" /> The appearance of the first eukaryotic cells in the fossil record were relatively followed by evidence of complex [[multicellular life]]. Rocks in Nevada dating back to a billion years ago preserve trace fossils left behind by [[worm]]s as they burrowed through the sediment.<ref name="audubon-multicellular-40" /> Other complex Precambrian lifeforms were preserved in North Carolina<ref name="north-carolina-paleoportal-general" /> and Arizona.<ref name="50states-arizona-93" />
==Paleozoic== [[File:Trilobitegrowth.jpg|thumb|right|125px|''[[Elrathia]]''.]] The Phanerozoic eon began following the Precambrian. The first major unit of time it contained was the Cambrian period of the Paleozoic era.<ref name="audubon-cambrian-42" /> At the time, earth's continents were in a very different arrangement and were generally smaller than they are today. The southeastern part of the US was connected to South America and Africa and located in the polar latitudes of the southern hemisphere. The western states were located near the equator.<ref name="audubon-continents-42" />
All known life during the [[Cambrian]] was aquatic so areas of the United States above sea level would have been sterile wastelands.<ref name="audubon-terrestrial-44" /> [[Trilobites]] are the most common kind of animal in the Cambrian fossil record.<ref name="audubon-otherinverts-43" /> Especially notable are the ''[[Elrathia]]'' of the [[Antelope Springs]] region of Utah.<ref name="50states-utah-273" /> [[Sponge]]-like [[archaeocyathids]] were common in Nevada.<ref name="audubon-otherinverts-43" /> [[Brachiopods]], gastropods, and sponges were also important Cambrian animals.<ref name="audubon-otherinverts-43-44" /> Sea levels around North America dropped at the end of the Cambrian. Ecosystems in shallow water probably devastated.<ref name="audubon-boundary-45" /> The Cambrian ended with a [[mass extinction]]. Globally, brachiopods and gastropods lost much of their biodiversity, sponges lost about half of their [[Family (taxonomy)|families]] and almost three quarters of contemporary trilobite families vanished at the same time.<ref name="audubon-mass-44" />
Much of the continent would be submerged when the sea finally rose again.<ref name="audubon-boundary-45" /> The most common animal in the [[Ordovician]] fossil record seems to have been brachiopods. Large numbers flourished and were preserved in great detail near [[Cincinnati]] during the [[Middle Ordovician]]. Members of this fauna were preserved in Indiana, Kentucky, and Ohio.<ref name="audubon-invert-45-46" /> Most known Ordovician trilobites are distinct from their Cambrian forbears as the few taxa surviving the mass extinction diversified once again.<ref name="audubon-invert-46" /> During the Middle Ordovician, early armored [[Jawless fish|jawless]] [[fish]] called [[ostracoderms]] left behind fragmentary shards of bone in what is now the [[Rocky Mountains]] region.<ref name="audubon-vert-47" /> Late in the Ordovician sea levels dropped.<ref name="audubon-level-48" /> Another mass extinction marked the end of the Ordovician. Globally, 25% of families disappeared. Major losses were experienced by brachiopods, fishes, [[echinoids]], [[sponges]] and trilobites. This mass extinction was also most damaging to trilobites, which lost 50% of their families.<ref name="audubon-mass-47" /> [[File:Eurypterus Paleoart.jpg|thumb|left|125px|''[[Eurypterus]]''.]] During the [[Silurian]], warm, shallow seas covered most of North America. Illinois, Indiana, and Michigan were home to vast [[coral reefs]].<ref name="audubon-level-48" /> The reefs of Indiana in particular are among the most diverse of the period on the entire continent.<ref name="reefs-abstract-7" /> The southeastern United States were still part of Gondwanaland during the Silurian.<ref name="audubon-silurian-48" /> Graptolites still inhabited the waters near the eastern coast of the United States but were not as big a component of the Silurian fauna as they used to be during the Ordovician.<ref name="audubon-seas-49" /> As the Silurian progressed the seas covering most of the country would retreat. Only the Michigan and New York areas (then near the [[equator]]) were still inundated. However, these landlocked seas were not being replenished by freshwater and so gradually evaporated, leaving concentrated [[salt]] deposits in those regions.<ref name="audubon-level-48" />
[[Devonian]] North America once again experience home to seas that teemed with life. In fact Devonian marine life may have been more abundant and diverse than at any other point in the Paleozoic.<ref name="audubon-devonian-50" /> [[Glass sponges]] became abundant in western New York during the Devonian.<ref name="audubon-invert-50" /> Especially notable are the marine fossils of [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio]], which was home to more than 120 kinds of marine life. The local fishes alone left behind more than 50,000 fossils.<ref name="50states-ohio-233-234" /> During the Late Devonian the oldest known [[seed]]-bearing plants grew in Pennsylvania. The plants responsible for leaving behind the local fossil seeds may have been [[seed ferns]], plants whose fronds resemble ferns but who reproduce through seeds instead of [[spores]].<ref name="audubon-seed-53" /> [[Gilboa Forest]], among the first in the world, formed in New York around this time.<ref name="50states-newyork-212" /> The Devonian ended with another mass extinction. Globally, 25% of families were lost. Nearly every family of [[ammonoids]], fishes, and [[amphibians]] became extinct. Most known families of coral and trilobite became extinct. Other taxa to suffer declines in diversity include brachiopods, [[bryozoans]], [[crinoids]], and [[ostracodes]].<ref name="audubon-mass-53" /> [[File:Crinoïde Carbonifère 8127.jpg|thumb|right|100px|''[[Agaricocrinus]]''.]] The ensuing [[Mississippian age|Mississippian]] has been nicknamed the Age of Crinoids because this group left behind such abundant fossils. Other common lifeforms include their relatives the [[blastoids]].<ref name="audubon-crinoids-54" /> The pinhead-sized [[foraminiferan]] ''[[Endothyra]]'' fed on seafloor detritus and was extremely abundant during the Mississippian. Some limestones in Illinois and Missouri that formed at this time are almost entirely composed of its remains.<ref name="audubon-forams-55" /> Few fossils of terrestrial life are known from the Mississippian of North America.<ref name="audubon-land-55" />
During the ensuing Pennsylvanian, the northward drift of [[Gondwanaland]] finally joined the southeastern United States to North America as [[Pangaea]] began to form. Mountain building raised the [[Ancestral Rockies]] in Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming. Seawaters left the interior of the country.<ref name="audubon-pennsylvanian-56" /> Densely vegetated swamps were widespread.<ref name="audubon-coalswamps-56" /> The largest insects in geologic history lived during the Pennsylvanian.<ref name="audubon-terrinvert-57" /> Giant salamander-like amphibians left behind footprints near Lawrence, Kansas that would later fossilize.<ref name="audubon-terraverts-57" /> Fossil footprints from this time period were also preserved in eastern states like Alabama, Georgia, West Virginia, Ohio, and Pennsylvania where Carboniferous fossil footprints are known.<ref name="dinotracksna-ageamphib-34" /> [[File:Dimetrodon8DB.jpg|thumb|left|125px|'[[Dimetrodon]]''.]] The world's continents were joined as Pangaea throughout all of the [[Permian]]. [[Volcanic]] activity occurred on the west coast. Seas were present in the southwest and west coast.<ref name="audubon-permian-58" /> The seas of Texas were home to massive reefs made of spined brachiopods jumbled together.<ref name="audubon-marinvert-58" /> Seas that had previously covered Kansas, New Mexico and Texas began drying up and left behind salt deposits. The inner portions of the western United States had a hot dry climate. [[Sand dunes]] were common throughout the country.<ref name="audubon-permian-58" /> The insects of the Permian were common and diverse, but smaller than those of the Pennsylvanian. An example of this bounty were the twenty different orders preserved at a site called Insect Hill near [[Elmo, Kansas]].<ref name="audubon-insects-59" /> Massive amphibians were not rare in the southwestern United States but were unable to stray too far from bodies of water.<ref name="audubon-amphib-59" /> ''[[Seymouria]]'' was a twenty inch long transitional form documenting the origin of reptiles from their amphibian-like forbears from Texas.<ref name="50states-texas-270" /> Reptiles were becoming common during the Permian.<ref name="audubon-reptiles-59" /> Texas was also home to the pelycosaurs ''[[Dimetrodon]]'' and ''[[Edaphosaurus]]''.<ref name="50states-texas-270" /> Late in the Permian therapsids became the dominant large-bodied terrestrial vertebrates. These were the precursors of mammals.<ref name="audubon-therapsids-60" />
The Permian ended with the most destructive mass extinction in all of earths history. Globally up to 96% of all species may have disappeared.<ref name="audubon-mass-60" /> [[Rugose coral|Rugose]] and [[tabulate corals]] became extinct.<ref name="audubon-extinctseas-60" /> The [[cryptostome]] and [[trepostome]] [[bryozoans]] also became extinct at this time despite their long history of diversity and abundance earlier in the Paleozoic. Brachiopods suffered greatly and never regained their previous numbers or variety. [[Ammonoids]] lost all but one family. [[Eurypterids]] and trilobites became extinct. Blastoids became extinct. Crinoids lost all but one family. The echinoids just squeaked past; only one genus is known to have survived. Typical survivors were small detritivores and sediments feeders. The worst losses were among filter feeders and carnivores.<ref name="audubon-extinctseas-61" />
==Mesozoic== [[File:Pangaea continents.svg|thumb|right|150px|Map of [[Pangaea]] with modern continents outlined.]] The eastern United States was part of [[Pangaea]]'s interior for most of the [[Triassic Period]] of the Mesozoic era. At the time, the area lay close to the equator and was connected to western [[Europe]] and [[Africa]]. The union of all of Earth's continents into a single land mass changed the way the [[atmosphere]] and oceans [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulated]]. This left what is now the eastern US with a hot climate and pronounced seasons.<ref name="eastcoast-triassicbeginnings-33" /> Much of the country was located at about 30 latitudinal degrees North, where there tends to be high atmospheric pressures and little precipitation. The western United States were largely covered in seawater during the Late Triassic. Mountain building and volcanic activity were ongoing in the same region.<ref name="audubon-plates-63" />
The Triassic saw the Earth's biosphere recovering from the [[end-Permian mass extinction]].<ref name="eastcoast-triassicbeginnings-33" /> After the Permian mass extinction, ammonoids were one of the first groups of marine invertebrates to become abundant and diverse again.<ref name="eastcoast-triassicbeginnings-33" /><ref name="audubon-marineinverts-63-64" /> During the Middle Triassic the scleractinian corals typical of modern oceans appeared. During the Triassic, corals were rare in North America. Nevertheless, some were present on the west coast, although these corals did not congregate into reefs.<ref name="audubon-marineinverts-64" /> Ichthyosaurs were one of the most important groups of marine reptiles during the Triassic. Important ichthyosaur fossils of this age were preserved in Nevada.<ref name="audubon-ichtyo-65" />
On land, North America's vegetation included plants like [[conifers]], [[cycads]], [[fern]]s, [[ginkgoes]], and [[horsetails]].<ref name="eastcoast-triassicbeginnings-33" /> The Triassic vegetation of the east coast indicated swampy conditions in the local rift valleys. Arizona was home to a great forest that would later leave behind the area's famous petrified wood.<ref name="audubon-landplants-64" /> Reptiles first began claiming the ecological dominance of marine, terrestrial and aerial habitats during the Triassic that would earn the Mesozoic the nickname "the Age of Reptiles".<ref name="audubon-age-64" />
The Late Triassic also saw the origin of the dinosaurs.<ref name="audubon-dinos-64" /> [[Dinosaurs]] left behind abundant fossils in the [[Four Corners]] region and this area is now known as one of the best sources of Late Triassic dinosaur fossils in the United States. Texas is also good source of dinosaur remains from this time.<ref name="eastcoast-pangaeastory-87" /> The oldest dinosaur remains in the eastern US are about 225 million years old.<ref name="eastcoast-eastcoastdist-88-89" /> So, dinosaurs had reached the east coast of the United States not long after they evolved in the first place.<ref name="eastcoast-latetriassicdinos-86" /> [[Fossil footprints]] are the most common kind of early dinosaur fossil in the eastern United States.<ref name="eastcoast-eastcoastdist-89" />
As the Triassic ended, Pangaea was breaking up into separate continents again. [[Rift valleys]] formed along the east coast as the North American, European and African plates diverged.<ref name="eastcoast-newark-36" /> This process created rifts down the east coast to Florida.<ref name="audubon-plates-63" /> One of these rift valleys was inundated with ocean water and became the young [[Atlantic Ocean]]. Volcanism related to the tectonic processes fracturing Pangaea also left deposits in the eastern US.<ref name="eastcoast-newark-34" /> At the end of the Triassic another mass extinction occurred.<ref name="eastcoast-newark-36" /> Globally, this extinction event wiped out roughly one quarter of families. Conodonts went completely extinct. Ammonoids barely survived. Brachiopods lost much of their former diversity as well. On land, most families of amphibians and reptiles became extinct.<ref name="audubon-mass-66" /> [[File:Diplodocus carnegii.jpg|left|thumb|200px|''[[Diplodocus carnegii]]''.]] The eastern coast of the US became warmer and wetter during the Early Jurassic because the newly formed Atlantic Ocean brought it into contact with more humid air.<ref name="eastcoast-newark-36" /> Fossils from spanning from the Late Triassic to [[Early Jurassic]] were preserved in the [[Newark Supergroup]], which is found between the Canadian province Nova Scotia and South Carolina.<ref name="eastcoast-eastcoastdist-87-88" /> Rifting continued in the eastern part of the country during the Early Jurassic as the eastern United States drifted apart from Greenland and Europe. The Pacific Plate forced its way under the North American plate, triggering geologic upheaval, including volcanism, on the west coast.<ref name="audubon-plates-67" /> Ichthyosaurs remained the dominant marine reptiles of the Early Jurassic, but as the Jurassic progressed that title was gradually transferred to the plesiosaurs.<ref name="audubon-marinereptiles-69" />
The stratigraphic unit known as the Morrison Formation was deposited during the Late Jurassic.<ref name="foster-road-tripping-3" /> These sediments are now exposed in Arizona, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Utah, Colorado, Wyoming, South Dakota, and Montana.<ref name="foster-rainbow-2" /> At the time, this region of the country was home to forests of conifers, ginkgos, and tree ferns. Coal would later form from the remains of these plants.<ref name="audubon-plants-68" /> Local mammals diversified significantly during the Jurassic. The Morrison Formation is the best source of Jurassic mammal fossils in North America.<ref name="audubon-mammals-70" /> Local dinosaurs included the [[ornithopod]] ''[[Camptosaurus]]'', the [[sauropods]] ''[[Apatosaurus]]'' and ''[[Diplodocus]]'', and the [[theropod]] ''[[Allosaurus]]''.<ref name="bigsky-jurassic-62" /> Unlike many periods of geologic history the Jurassic did not end in a mass extinction. There were, however, lesser extinction events going on at the time, with notable losses occurring among ammonoids and dinosaurs.<ref name="audubon-end-70" />
During the Early Cretaceous the Gulf of Mexico began gradually expanding northward.<ref name="audubon-rocks-72" /> On land, the eastern United States during resembled the modern [[Mississippi Delta]]. It was a lowlying plain divided by rivers. A thick coat of vegetation covered the region in plants like [[club mosses]], [[conifers]], [[cycads]], [[fern]]s, [[ginkgoes]], [[horsetails]]. and early [[flowers]].<ref name="eastcoast-eccoast-44" /> [[File:Rjpalmer tyrannosaurusrex (white background).jpg|thumb|right|200px|''[[Tyrannosaurus rex]]''.]] During the Late Cretaceous the Gulf of Mexico had expanded through North America until reaching Alaska.<ref name="audubon-rocks-72" /> Up to half of the continent's modern surface area may have been submerged by this sea.<ref name="eastcoast-latecretaceousparadise-47" /> This is called the Western Interior Seaway.<ref name="oceans-oneday-6" /> It covered the majority of states like Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, the Dakotas, and Wyoming.<ref name="oceans-oneday-5" /> The seafloor was smooth and probably never submerged by more than 600 feet of water. A great diversity of invertebrates flourished both on the bottom and in the water column. Examples include [[ammonites]], [[giant clams]], [[crinoids]], [[rudists]], and [[squid]]. Vertebrate life included [[bony fish]]es, [[mosasaurs]], [[plesiosaurs]], [[shark]]s, and [[turtle]]s.<ref name="oceans-oneday-7" /> Areas now occupied by the plains of the east coast from New Jersey southward as well as the Gulf coast region were covered in seawater during the Cretaceous.<ref name="audubon-rocks-71-72" /> Sea levels reached their highest level in all of geologic history during the Cretaceous, although they declined before the period ended.<ref name="audubon-cretaceous-71" /> Scleractinian corals were more diverse during the Cretaceous than they are today. Back then coral reefs formed along the Gulf coast.<ref name="audubon-corals-72" /> Rudist bivalves also constructed reefs in the Gulf coast region.<ref name="audubon-mollusks-72-73" /> Another bivalve, Exogyra, was so common its fossils are found in almost every Cretaceous marine deposit.<ref name="audubon-mollusks-73" /> During the Cretaceous, the dominant group of living fishes, the teleosts, first achieved ascendency over their holostean forbears.<ref name="audubon-teleosts-73" /> The aquatic toothed bird Hesperornis is the only known Cretaceous bird whose remains are found with any frequency in North America.<ref name="audubon-birds-74" />
Near the end of the Cretaceous, the Western Interior Seaway began to withdraw. This regression would end up resulting in both halves of North America reuniting. As the seaway withdrew a coastal plain expanded southward into the northern part of the western interior.<ref name="bigsky-maastrichtian-77" /> Powerful geologic forces began to fold and distort the rocks of Idaho, Utah, and Wyoming, beginning the processes that would form the Rocky Mountains.<ref name="audubon-rockymts-72" /> Rivers flowing across the eastern part of what is now Montana, deposited the sediments now known as the [[Hell Creek Formation]]. At the time, Montana was home to some of the most famous dinosaurs; creatures like ''[[Edmontosaurus]]'', ''[[Pachycephalosaurus]]'', ''[[Triceratops]]'', and ''[[Tyrannosaurus]]''.<ref name="bigsky-maastrichtian-77" /> Despite the western upheaval, the eastern US had achieved geological stability by the [[Late Cretaceous]].<ref name="eastcoast-latecretaceousparadise-47" /> The weather was uniformly warm and rainy throughout the year.<ref name="eastcoast-latecretaceousparadise-48" /> Flowering plants were now common and fossil of [[broadleaf trees]] and [[shrubs]] were preserved in Late Cretaceous rocks.<ref name="eastcoast-latecretaceousparadise-48" />
The Cretaceous ended with another mass extinction. This one was the second most devastating in geologic history. Roughly half of all animal families became extinct. Ammonoids and belemnoids were among the marine invertebrates extinguished. Planktonic foraminiferans barely survived. Two thirds of coral species became extinct. About half of sponge families became extinct. Bivalves, bryozoans, and gastropods also sustained heavy losses. The major Mesozoic marine reptile groups became extinct. On land, the non-avian dinosaurs and pterosaurs became extinct.<ref name="audubon-mass-75" /> The most popular explanation for the mass extinction at the end of the Cretaceous is that it resulted from a meteorite impact. This impact would explain the presence of high levels of the heavy element iridium in sediments from the time. Iridium is very rare in earth's crust but much more common in meteors.<ref name="audubon-impact-75-76" /> Dinosaurs were widespread within the regions now composing the modern United States. Dinosaur fossils are known to have been preserved in [[Paleontology in Alabama|Alabama]],<ref name="carr-williamson-schwimmer-abstract" /> [[Paleontology in Alaska|Alaska]],<ref ==Cenozoic== [[File:Patriofelis22DB.jpg|thumb|right|125px|The creodont ''[[Patriofelis]]''.]] After the Cretaceous, a new era of geologic time began; the [[Cenozoic]] era, which means the era of "recent life". Traditionally, the first period of the Cenozoic was called the [[Tertiary]],<ref name="audubon-tertiary-77" /> however recent recommendations of the [[International Commission on Stratigraphy]] discourage its use, with the correspondent time span divided between the earlier [[Paleogene]] and the more recent [[Neogene]] periods.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ogg, James G. |author2=Gradstein, F. M |author3=Gradstein, Felix M. |title=A geologic time scale 2004|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, UK|year=2004|isbn=0-521-78142-6}}</ref> The geologic turmoil on the west coast was maintained as the [[Pacific Plate]] continued to slide under the [[North American Plate]].<ref name="audubon-plates-77" /> During the early part of the Cenozoic period climates were much warmer than they are today. Latitudes as high as South Dakota had a [[subtropical]] climate until as recently as the end of the [[Oligocene]].<ref name="audubon-level-77" />
Sea level fell throughout the Cenozoic.<ref name="audubon-level-77" /> Areas of Cenozoic North America that were covered by seawater tended to be areas near the modern coasts.<ref name="audubon-rocks-78" /> The [[Cannonball Sea]] near [[Minot, North Dakota]] was the last of the North American interior.<ref name="50states-northdakota-224" /> Cenozoic marine invertebrates are best known from deposits near the coasts and tend to resemble modern forms. [[Solitary corals]] became common, but coral reefs formed only around the Gulf of Mexico.<ref name="audubon-marineinverts-78" /> [[Sharks]] were common during the Cenozoic.<ref name="audubon-fishes-78" /> From [[Eocene]] times onward they began increasing in size.<ref name="audubon-fishes-79" />
The beginning of the Cenozoic was also the beginning of the Age of Mammals. The small [[shrew]]-like generalist [[insectivores]] that survived the Late Cretaceous extinction event began diversifying into the mammals that dominate the modern world's terrestrial ecosystems.<ref name="audubon-age-79" /> The [[creodonts]], which first appeared in the [[Paleocene]], were among the first mammals to specialize in carnivory.<ref name="audubon-carnivores-81" /> The coastal region of the southeastern states, like Alabama<ref name="50states-alabama-86" /> and Mississippi<ref name="50states-mississippi-171" /> were covered in seawater and home to the primitive whale ''[[Basilosaurus]]'' during the Eocene. The diversity of mammalian carnivores on land increased from the Eocene to the Miocene.<ref name="audubon-carnivores-81" /> [[File:Megacerops 10.jpg|thumb|left|150px|''[[Brontotherium]]''.]] Around the same time, [[camels]] were becoming common in North America, although they were just barely bigger than modern [[rabbits]] during the Eocene. Early camels had four toes.<ref name="audubon-camels-80" /> During the early part of the Eocene the first primitive [[horses]] also began appearing. Among the earliest was ''[[Eohippus]]'', a small animal with four toes on the front feet and three on the rear.<ref name="audubon-horses-79" /> A group of mammals called [[oreodonts]] also appeared during the Eocene.<ref name="audubon-oreodonts-80" /> By the Oligocene, camels were the size of [[sheep]] and had only two toes.<ref name="audubon-camels-80" /> Gradually over time horses also lost toes, but unlike camels, horses' were reduced to a single digit.<ref name="audubon-horses-79" /> By the Oligocene their teeth had adapted to endure abrasion from [[silica]] in their increasingly [[grass]]y diets.<ref name="audubon-horses-79" /> Horses gradually became common throughout the country.<ref name="audubon-horses-79" /> Large numbers of oreodonts grazed in the badlands of South Dakota by the middle of the Cenozoic.<ref name="audubon-oreodonts-80" /> Oreodonts were vaguely pig like and about the size of modern [[goats]]. Their numbers peaked during the Oligocene.<ref name="audubon-oreodonts-80" /> The largest mammals of Oligocene North America were the [[rhinoceros]]-like [[titanotheres]]. One spectacular example was the abundant ''[[Brontotherium]]'' of South Dakota, which could be up to 8 feet tall at the shoulder. Despite their early success, by the end of the epoch the entire group became extinct.<ref name="audubon-titanotheres-80" /> [[File:Woolly mammoth (Mammuthus primigenius) - Mauricio Antón.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Wooly mammoths]].]] Following the Oligocene temperatures began to decline, and with it warm-weather vegetation was forced southward into lower latitudes.<ref name="audubon-level-77" /> By the [[Miocene]] some sharks, which had been increasing in size since the Eocene, were over 60 feet long.<ref name="audubon-fishes-79" /> [[Mastodons]] arrived in North America by crossing the [[Bering land bridge]] from the old world during the Miocene as well.<ref name="audubon-proboscideans-81" /> The oreodonts became extinct during the [[Pliocene]].<ref name="audubon-oreodonts-80" /> By the time the Pliocene ended more modern [[Carnivora|carnivores]] like [[wolves]] and [[cat]]s appeared. Notable among the latter group were the [[saber-toothed cat]]s.<ref name="audubon-carnivores-81" /> [[Woolly mammoth]]s became abundant across the US during the late Cenozoic.<ref name="audubon-proboscideans-81" /> During the late [[Pleistocene]], the large volumes of water were held frozen as part of [[glacier]]s. This caused a drop in sea level, which exposed a land bridge between Asia and Alaska. [[Settlement of the Americas|Humans crossed over this bridge]] and started becoming abundant in North America between 11,000 and 12,000 years ago.<ref name="audubon-humans-84" /> Despite withstanding the fluctuating climate and concomitant advance and retreat of glaciers, around 10,000 years ago around 32 genera of large mammals suddenly became extinct.<ref name="audubon-migrations-84-85" /> Horses were locally extirpated during these end-Pleistocene megafauna extinctions.<ref name="audubon-horses-79" /> Some paleontologists attribute these extinctions to the arrival of early humans, who over hunted the local large game. Under this model, the disappearance of saber-toothed cats and other contemporary predators would be explained by the loss of their primary source of food. However, this explanation is still controversial.<ref name="audubon-mammal-85" />
